Emergency or temporary stopping or parking is permitted on any street, alley or highway for not longer than one (1) hour subject to any other and further prohibitions, regulations, or limitations imposed by the traffic and parking regulations or ordinances for that street, alley or highway. 
(3)  Accessory garage or yard. No person shall park or occupy any recreational vehicle on the premises of any occupied dwelling or on any lot which is not a part of the premises of any occupied dwelling, either of which is situated outside an approved recreational vehicle park, for more than five (5) days, except, the parking of only one (1) unoccupied recreational vehicle in an accessory private garage building or in a yard in any district is permitted, providing no living quarters shall be maintained or any business practiced in the recreational vehicle while such recreational vehicle is so parked or stored. Such vehicle may be allowed to obtain electric service but shall not connect to water or sewer service. 
(4)  Industrial zoning. The parking of only one (1) mobile home or recreational vehicle shall be allowed in the industrial areas of the city, that are so zoned, for the watchmen or office use, provided it is placed a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet from any building. 
Editor's note- For initial application fee, the user's attention is directed to § 15-4. 
(5)  Temporary offices, security. The parking of only one (1) mobile home or recreational vehicle is permitted on construction sites as temporary offices, or for security purposes during the period of construction and so long as the building permit at the site is valid, as provided under the building code. 
(6)  Medical necessity. The parking of only one (1) mobile home or recreational vehicle is permitted upon any other site within the city where the location thereof will not violate the setback requirements and it is not located in the front yard, and where it is medically necessary for the health, care and welfare of the trailer occupant to not live alone, and the close assistance of a family member is required for the health and care of the occupant as follows: 
a.  The occupant of the mobile home or recreational vehicle must be a close relative by blood or marriage, or a legal ward of the property owner then occupying the principal dwelling as their permanent residence. 
b.  Application for a permit pursuant to this subsection (6) shall be filed on a form provided by the city and certified by the building inspector that the property upon which it is proposed to locate the mobile home or recreational vehicle is not then in violation of any provision of this Code and the location thereof of such mobile home or recreational vehicle will not otherwise violate this Code. 
c.  The application shall have attached to it a current statement from a licensed physician in the state that the proposed mobile home or recreational vehicle occupant is, in the opinion of the doctor, unable to live alone and requires care and supervision from some family member and a statement of the medical condition of the patient existing on which the doctor bases his opinion. 
d.  When a permit is issued, the mobile home or recreational vehicle shall be located in the rear yard of the property back of the principal dwelling, fifteen (15) feet from the rear property line and at least five (5) feet total from the side lines of the parcel. 
e.  All mobile homes and recreational vehicles granted permits pursuant to this subsection (6) must be left with undercarriage and other equipment necessary for its removal and shall in no event be affixed in any permanent way to foundation. They shall, however, be tied down in accordance with the requirements of this Code in the regard for safety purposes. 
f.  The application shall contain the name of the manufacturer of the mobile home or recreational vehicle, year of manufacture, the model number, the dimensions of the mobile home or recreational vehicle and an actual color photograph of the exterior and any other information requested by the city. The permit, when issued, shall be issued for that particular vehicle, at a specific location only, and at all times they shall be maintained in an attractive manner and kept in compliance with all Code requirements for safety and health. A mobile home or recreational vehicle may be substituted for an existing mobile home or recreational vehicle by appropriate application and amended permit. 
g.  Renewal shall be upon annual application on a simplified form in which the applicant certifies that the original conditions of the application still exist. 
h.  No permit will be issued to any person, except an owner who occupies the principal dwelling at the site at all times as his home and residence. In the event of the death of the occupant of the mobile home or recreational vehicle, the mobile home or recreational vehicle occupant ceases to actually live and reside in the mobile home or recreational vehicle for a continuing period of thirty (30) days (except time spent in a hospital shall not count), or the medical condition required by this subsection (6) of the mobile home or recreational vehicle occupant ceases to exist, or the owner of the property ceases to make the principal dwelling on the site their permanent home; all permits issued pursuant to this subsection (6) shall be null and void. The owner shall remove such mobile home or recreational vehicle from the premises within sixty (60) days of such termination. 
i.  Reserved. 
j.  No such mobile home or recreational vehicle may be rented to any person and no personal shall pay the owner any rent or other form of compensation as rent for such use. 
(7)  Church property. The parking of only one (1) mobile home or recreation vehicle is permitted on church property (utilized for worship) for security purposes. 
(8)  Agricultural use. The parking of only one (1) mobile home or recreation vehicle is permitted as an accessory use to a principal bona fide agriculture use under the following conditions: 
a.  Bona fide agriculture shall apply to any plot of land where the principal use consists of the growing, cultivation and harvesting of crops; the raising of animals, inclusive of aviculture, aquaculture, horses and livestock; the production of animal products such as eggs, honey or dairy products; or the raising of plant material. The determination as to whether or not the use of land is considered bona fide agriculture shall be made pursuant of F.S. § 823.24, Florida Right to Farm Act. 
b.  The minimum lot size for the parking of one (1) mobile home or recreation vehicle as an accessory use shall be two and one-half (2.5) acres. 
c.  The mobile home may be substituted and sold together with the land consisting of the bona fide agricultural use. 
(Code 1984, § 24-2; Ord. No. 92-3, § 1, 6-9-1992; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-3. - Permits continued from August 10, 2010; conditions. 
    In addition to the permitted mobile home and recreational vehicles provided for in section 15-2, all lawfully issued mobile home or recreational vehicle permits which were issued and outstanding as of August 10, 2010 and whose permit holders maintained and continued their current use and status of such mobile home or recreational vehicle, were, and shall continue to be allowed to maintain and continue the same use and status of such mobile home or recreational vehicle which was in effect on August 10, 2010, provided that: 
(1)  The permit holder makes proper annual application for renewal on the form furnished by the city on or before September 1, 2010, for the permit year of October 1, 2010, to September 30, 2011, and thereafter made proper annual application for renewal. 
(2)  The permittee pays applicable application and permit fees. 
(3)  There has been no change in the location or the mobile home or recreational vehicle described in the permit has not been substituted with any other mobile home or recreational vehicle since August 10, 2010. 
(4)  The ownership of the real property upon which the mobile home or recreational vehicle is located has not changed since August 10, 2010. The transfer of the real property by any means, or any part thereof as described in the permit, the death of the owner of the permit, or the destruction or removal of the vehicle from the permit premises shall all constitute a termination of the permit issued pursuant to section 15-2. No permit issued pursuant to section 15-2 shall be transferable, nor any rights therein. All permits issued pursuant to section 15-2 shall have the words "Restricted Permit" imprinted, stamped, or written across, or on the face of the permit. 
(5)  The city may grant an exception to the disallowance of continued permitting of any mobile homes or recreational vehicles allowed under this section when the mobile home or recreational vehicle has been lawfully parked in an area that was designated as a "trailer park" or "recreational vehicle park" on August 10, 2010, but has been since rezoned or reclassified and no longer designated as a "trailer park." 
(Code 1984, § 24-3; Ord. No. 92-6, § 1, 10-13-1992; Ord. No. 93-1, § 1, 2-13-1993; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-4. - Application and fees. 
    Any property owner requesting to situate a mobile home or recreational vehicle on their property for the first time shall file an application for a permit and all required documentation along with a nonrefundable application fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) on a form provided by the city. The annual permit fee shall be as set forth below payable when the permit is issued and the permit shall run from October 1 to the next succeeding September 13. A partial year's permit may be issued for any portion of a year's remaining from the date of approval of the permit prorated by month. Each partial month shall count as a full month for the purpose of computation of the fee. 
The following shall be submitted with new applications for location of a mobile home or recreational vehicle: 
(1)  The written consent of all owners of the lands within one hundred (100) feet of the exterior property line of the applicant's property where the mobile home or recreational vehicle is to be located, the description of which shall be determined by the parcel as described in the current tax roll. This shall not apply to mobile homes or recreational vehicles located on industrial property or construction sites. 
(2)  A certification by the building inspector that the property upon which it is proposed to locate the mobile home or recreational vehicle is not then in violation of any provision of this Code and the location thereof of such mobile home or recreational vehicle will not otherwise violate this Code. 
(3)  The application shall contain the name of the manufacturer of the mobile home or recreational vehicle, year of manufacture, the model number, the dimensions of the mobile home or recreational vehicle and an actual color photograph of the exterior, the proposed location of the mobile home or recreational vehicle on the site and any other information requested by the city. The permit, when issued shall be issued for that particular vehicle, at a specific location only, and at all times they shall be maintained in an attractive manner and kept in compliance with all Code requirements for safety and health. A mobile home or recreational vehicle may be substituted for an existing mobile home or recreational vehicle by appropriate application and amended permit. 
(4)  All renewal permits shall be required to provide subsections (2) and (3) of this section. 

Type Permit Annual Renewal Necessary? Renewal Fee Recreational Vehicle Park No No fee for industrial vehicles/homes. Accessory Garage/Yard Yes $75.00 Industrial Zoning/Watchman Office Yes $75.00 Medical Necessity Yes $75.00 Church Property/Worship Yes $75.00 Security Bona Fide Agricultural Yes* $75.00* Sec. 15-3 Permits Yes $75.00  
*Unless mobile home is taxed by the property appraiser as part of the real property, then no annual 
 renewal and no annual fee. 
(Code 1984, § 24-4; Ord. No. 2007-12, § 1, 8-28-2007; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Secs. 15-5-15-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-26. - Zoning restrictions; exceptions. 
(a)  No recreational vehicle park shall be located in any district other than C-1, C-2, and I. 
(b)  The board of adjustments may in conformance with the zoning laws, recommend, and authorize to be issued, a license for the location of such a facility. 
(c)  No recreational vehicle park shall be located within the limits of the city unless adequate city water and sanitary sewerage disposal and fire protection facilities are made available. 
(d)  No occupied recreational vehicle or park cottage or cabin or other building shall be located within the city within the recognized setback line for the zoning district in which such recreational vehicle or cabin is located nor less than ten (10) feet from any other building or vehicle or the boundary line of the tract on which located. 
(Code 1984, § 24-17; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-27. - General requirements. 
(a)  Every recreational vehicle park shall be located on a well-drained area, and the premises shall be properly graded so as to prevent the accumulation of stormwaters and other waters. 
(b)  Units and cabin plots shall be clearly designated and the park so arranged that all units and cabin plots shall face or about on a driveway not less than sixteen (16) feet in width, giving easy access from all units to a public street. Such driveway shall be paved and maintained in good condition, well lighted at night, and shall not be obstructed. 
(c)  No park cottage or cabin shall be less than two hundred eighty (280) square feet in area nor less than fourteen (14) feet wide at its narrowest point, and not less than eight (8) feet high from floor to ceiling and shall not have less than twenty-seven (27) square feet of ventilating openings, and all windows must be fully screened. 
(d)  The park shall be so laid out that no unit or cabin shall be located farther than two hundred (200) feet from the toilets and service buildings provided for in this article. 
(e)  Every unit shall be furnished with an electric service outlet. Such outlet shall be equipped with an externally operated switch or fuse of not less than thirty (30) amperes capacity and a heavy duty outlet receptacle. 
(Code 1984, § 24-18; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-28. - Water supply. 
(a)  An adequate supply of pure water, furnished through a pipe distribution system connected directly with the city water main, with supply faucets located at each recreational vehicle or cabin, shall be required. 
(b)  No common drinking vessels shall be permitted, nor shall any drinking water faucets be placed in any toilet room or water closet compartment. 
(c)  An abundant supply of hot water shall be provided at all times for bathing, washing, and laundry facilities. 
(Code 1984, § 24-19; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Cross reference- Water generally, § 26-26 et seq. 
Sec. 15-29. - Service building and facilities. 
(a)  Every recreational vehicle park shall have erected thereon, at a distance not greater than two hundred (200) feet from any unit or cabin it is designed to serve, a suitable building for housing, toilets, showers, and laundry facilities. Such building shall be known as the service building. 
(b)  There shall be provided separate toilet rooms for each sex. Flush toilets provided with and adequate water supply shall be enclosed in separate compartments having a minimum width of four (4) feet and shall be provided for each sex in the ratio of one (1) toilet for each eight (8) units or cabins or fraction thereof. Every male toilet room shall have one (1) urinal for each sixteen (16) units or cabins, but in no case shall any male toilet be without a urinal. Toilet rooms shall contain lavatories with hot and cold water in the ratio of one (1) lavatory to every two (2) or less water closets. 
(c)  Separate bathing facilities for each sex shall be provided with one (1) shower enclosed in a compartment at least four (4) feet square for each eight (8) units or cabins or fraction thereof. Each shower compartment shall be supplemented by an individual dressing compartment of at least twelve (12) square feet. 
(d)  Laundry facilities shall be provided in the ratio of one (1) double tray and one (1) ironing board for each ten (10) units or cabins. 
(e)  The above accommodations shall be based on the total park capacity according to accepted plans. 
(f)  Floors of toilets, showers, and the laundry shall be of concrete, tile, or similar material impervious to water and easily cleaned and pitched to a floor drain. 
(Code 1984, § 24-20; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Cross reference- Sewers generally, § 26-91 et seq. 
Sec. 15-30. - Garbage and waste disposal. 
    All waste and garbage shall be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1984, § 24-21; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Cross reference- Garbage and trash generally, Ch. 11. 
Sec. 15-31. - Limitation on occupants of trailers. 
    No recreational vehicle or cabin may be inhabited by a greater number of occupants than that for which it was designed. 
(Code 1984, § 24-22; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-32. - Management of parks; compliance with laws. 
(a)  In every recreational vehicle park there shall be an office building in which shall be located the office of the person in charge of the park. A copy of the park license and of this article shall be posted therein, and the park register shall be at all times kept in the office. 
(b)  It is hereby made the duty of the attendant or person in charge, together with the licensee, to comply at all times with the city, county and state laws governing recreational vehicle parks. 
(Code 1984, § 24-23; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-33. - Applicability of technical regulations. 
    All plumbing, electrical and other work on or at any park licensed under this article shall be in accordance with the provisions of the ordinances of the city regulating such work unless the provisions are specifically made inapplicable under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 24-24; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-34. - Recreational vehicles in mobile home parks. 
(a)  Transient recreational vehicles shall not be allowed in mobile home parks. Transient recreational vehicles shall mean any recreational vehicle that does not have a written lease agreement for more than six (6) months. A month-to-month rental shall be considered transient. 
(b)  Non-transient recreational vehicles shall be allowed in mobile home parks provided the owner first obtains a permit from the city. Permits shall be granted by the city to recreational vehicle owners who desire to keep their recreational vehicles in a mobile home park which meet the following conditions: 
(1)  Payment of application fee; 
(2)  Completion of application; 
(3)  Supplies the city with a copy of their lease; 
(4)  The mobile home park has supplied the city with a copy of its plan to provide services to the recreational vehicle, including a description of water, sewer, electric, and all utility provisions; 
(5)  The mobile home park is in compliance with F.S. ch. 513, and has a current permit from the county health department for a mobile home park, that also rents to non-transient recreational vehicles; and 
(6)  The applicant for the permit agrees to comply with the mobile home parks' rules regarding approaching severe weather, and a copy of the rules must be on file with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 4-10-2012) 
Secs. 15-35-15-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational licenses and business regulations, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 15-46. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or maintain, or permit to be established, operated or maintained upon any property owned or controlled by him, a recreational vehicle park within the limits of the city without having first secured a license therefore, from the tax collector, granted and existing in compliance with the terms of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 24-4(a); Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-47. - Application. 
    The application for such license shall be filed with the tax collector. The application shall be made on printed forms furnished by the tax collector, and shall include the name and address of the owner in fee of the tract (if the fee is vested in some person other than the applicant, a duly verified statement by that person that the applicant is authorized by him to construct or maintain the recreational vehicle park and make the application), and a legal description of the premises. The application shall be accompanied by two (2) copies of the park plan showing the following, either existing or as proposed: 
(1)  The extent and area used for park purposes; 
(2)  Roadways and driveways; 
(3)  Location of sites or units for recreational vehicles or cabins; 
(4)  Location and number of sanitary conveniences, including toilets, washrooms, laundries and utility rooms, to be used by occupants of units or cabins (in cases where cabins do not have all such facilities in proper conformance with city building, plumbing and other codes); 
(5)  Method and plan of sewage disposal; 
(6)  Method and plan of garbage removal; 
(7)  Plan for water supply; 
(8)  Plan for electrical lighting of units and cabins. 
(Code 1984, § 24-4(b); Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-48. - Recommendation and inspection of premises by board of investigators. 
    Before a license may be issued pursuant to this article there must be a favorable recommendation by a majority of the board of investigators and the premises must be inspected and approved by each of the members of the board of investigators, or their duly authorized representative, as complying with all the provisions of this article and all other applicable provisions of the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 24-4(c); Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-49. - Interpretation of license relative to building, plumbing, electrical work. 
    Licenses issued pursuant to this article convey no right to erect any building, to do any plumbing work or to do any electrical work. 
(Code 1984, § 24-4(d); Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-50. - Revocation-Grounds. 
    The board of investigators is hereby authorized to revoke any license issued pursuant to the terms of this article if after due investigation it determines that the holder thereof has violated any of the provisions of this article or that any recreational vehicle or park is being maintained in an unsanitary or unsafe manner or is a nuisance. 
(Code 1984, § 24-25; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-51. - Same-Hearings. 
    Any person aggrieved by an order of the board of investigators granting, denying, renewing, or revoking a license for a recreational park issued pursuant to this article, may file a written request for a hearing before the city commission within ten (10) days after issuance of such order. The board shall give notice of public hearing upon this request to be held in not less than five (5) days after service of the notice on the person requesting the hearing. The board may also give notice of the hearing to other persons directly interested in the order of the question. At such hearing, the board shall determine whether the granting, denial, renewal, or revocation of the license was in accordance with the provisions of this article and shall issue written findings of fact, conclusions of law, and order to carry out its findings and conclusions. These findings of fact, conclusions of law, and order shall be filed with the secretary of the board and served by the board upon all parties appearing or represented at the hearing. 
(Code 1984, § 24-26; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Sec. 15-52. - Same-Review by city commission. 
    Any order granting, denying, renewing, or revoking any license issued pursuant to this article may be appealed to the city commission in the same manner as appeals from any order under the building or zoning ordinances of the city. Appeals from such orders must be taken within ten (10) days after the order is issued. Upon any such appeal the findings of fact of the board of investigators, if supported by substantial evidence, shall be conclusive. 
(Code 1984, § 24-27; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Chapter 16 - OCCUPATIONAL LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; junkyards, § 13-51 et seq.; recreational vehicle parks, § 15-26 et seq.; license for recreational vehicle parks, § 15-46 et seq.; peddlers and solicitors for personal profit, § 21-26 et seq.; identification card and license for peddlers and solicitors, § 21-41 et seq.; transient or itinerant merchants or vendors, § 21-71 et seq.; license for transient or itinerant merchants or vendors, § 21-86 et seq.; permit for charitable solicitations, § 21-126 et seq.; taxation generally, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- Local occupational license taxes, F.S. Ch. 205. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Occupational tax imposed; when payable; duration; half-year licenses. 
(a)  An occupational tax is hereby imposed upon each and every business, profession and occupation engaged in or carried on, either wholly or in part within the corporate limits of the city, in the respective amount as provided for by section 16-10 and each and every person engaged in or carrying on, managing or practicing any business, profession or occupation, either wholly or in part within the corporate limits of the city is hereby required to pay to the city an occupational tax in the amount provided for by section 16-10. 
(b)  Such occupational license tax shall be payable not later than the first day of October each year and shall cover the period from such date to and ending on the thirtieth day of September the same year. Upon payment of such tax the city tax collector shall issue to the person paying the same a receipt or license signed by the city tax collector and the receipt or license shall expire on the thirtieth day of September next succeeding its issuance, unless otherwise especially provided for, except that if a person shall not begin to engage in such business, profession or occupation until after the first day of April of any year, he shall be required to pay only one-half of the amount of the tax. No license shall be issued for more than one (1) year. 
(Code 1984, § 14-1) 
State Law reference- Levy by municipalities, F.S. § 205.042. 
Sec. 16-2. - Individual licenses required for certain professions and businesses. 
    The occupational license for such professions or businesses as architects, auctioneers, auditors or accountants, dentists, civil engineers, lawyers, osteopaths, chiropractors, chiropodists, phrenologists, physicians or surgeons, real estate brokers or other similar professions shall be construed to mean that each individual shall pay the tax provided for by this chapter, whether practicing by himself or in partnership or employed by others. 
(Code 1984, § 14-2) 
Sec. 16-3. - Occupations and businesses in more than one classification. 
    Unless otherwise specified, when any occupation, business, profession or privilege shall fall into more than one (1) of the classifications contained in this chapter, such occupations, businesses, professions or privileges shall be required to comply with the license requirements of each such classification or provision. 
(Code 1984, § 14-3) 
Sec. 16-4. - Determination of license fee based on stock in trade or number of rooms. 
(a)  Whenever the amount of the license applied for depends upon the amount of stock in trade carried by the applicant, the tax collector shall use as a basis for such amount the most current figures in the city tax assessment files for the inventory of such business. If no such information is available, then the applicant shall state such amount as part of his written application. 
(b)  Where such license fee is based on the number of rooms in a hotel or roominghouse the owner of the business shall state such number in his original application and thereafter he shall notify the tax collector of any changes, additions or reductions before the annual renewal thereof if any and such license shall show upon its face the number of such units so licensed. 
(Code 1984, § 14-4) 
Sec. 16-5. - Transfer of license. 
(a)  Licenses may be transferred from one (1) location to another location provided that the licenses are presented to the tax collector for the approval of such transfer, and provided further, that the licensee shall pay for such transfer a fee in the amount of three dollars ($3.00). 
(b)  Licenses may be transferred with the approval of the tax collector with the businesses for which they were taken out, except as otherwise provided by law, when there is a bona fide sale and transfer of the property used and employed in the business as stock in trade, subject however to the following conditions: 
(1)  The seller of the business shall present the license to the tax collector with an endorsement on the reverse side thereof, assigning all right, title and interest to the purchaser. 
(2)  The purchaser shall produce for examination only, a properly executed instrument showing the stock of goods and the lease to the property. 
(3)  Where the licenses have been exempted from payment of all or any part of the license tax therefor, any such license shall not be transferable under this section. 
(4)  The essential nature of the business shall not be changed and there shall be continuity in operation of that business by the transferee. This paragraph applies to transfers with or without a change in location. 
(Code 1984, § 14-5) 
State Law reference- Transfers, F.S. § 205.043(2), (3). 
Sec. 16-6. - License not to protect person from prosecution; false statements. 
    No license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall protect any person from prosecution for transacting any business, trade or profession not covered by such license, or shall protect any merchant doing business with a greater stock in trade than covered by such license, or any hotel keeper or roominghouse keeper having a greater number of rooms than is covered by such license. Any license issued upon any false statement shall not protect the holder thereof from prosecution for transacting business without a license. 
(Code 1984, § 14-6) 
Sec. 16-7. - Evidence of liability for license. 
    As soon as any person engages in any business, profession or occupation in the city, he shall be liable for an occupational license. Regardless of when such occupation, business or profession commences no reduction shall be made in the amount of license except as set forth in section 16-1. 
(Code 1984, § 14-7) 
Sec. 16-8. - Responsibility for compliance with chapter. 
    Where the principal, master or employer has complied with provisions of this chapter it shall be unnecessary for his agent, servant or employee to comply herewith, unless otherwise expressly provided for in this chapter; provided, however, that if such principal, master or employer has not complied with this chapter, each of his agents, servants or employees shall be subject to prosecution, and upon conviction, to punishment to the same extent as his principal, master or employer. 
(Code 1984, § 14-8) 
Sec. 16-9. - Suspension, revocation, cancellation of license. 
    Any license issued by the city may be temporarily suspended or absolutely revoked or cancelled by a majority vote of the city commission, when the commission has ascertained and determined, in the exercise of its sound discretion, that such action will promote the public peace, health, safety, welfare, harmony or good order of the neighborhood in which the licensee's place of business is located. In the case of the revocation and cancellation of such license, the city shall refund to such licensee the prorated unearned or unused portion of his license. No refund, however, shall be made where the license is temporarily suspended. 
(Code 1984, § 14-9) 
Sec. 16-10. - Tax schedule. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall repeal the occupational license taxes as set forth in "The Code of Ordinances of the City of Pahokee, Florida," adopted in 1965, in sections 15-13 through 15-20 and 15-22. 
(Code 1984, § 14-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-1, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 23, 1995, amended the occupational license fee schedule set out in Exhibits A and B of Ord. No. 84-5, and §§ 15-13, 15-13.1 and 15-17 of the 1965 Code as referenced in § 16-10. Inasmuch as such provisions are not set out at length in this Code, the user is referred to Exhibit A attached to Ord. No. 95-1 for the specific fee amounts. Such ordinance and the attached exhibits are on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 16-11. - Effect of section 16-10 on taxes not included. 
    The provisions of section 16-10 shall not repeal any special ordinance fixing a special license tax for occupations not covered by section 16-10. 
(Code 1984, § 14-14) 
Sec. 16-12. - Delinquent penalties. 
(a)  Those licenses not renewed by October first shall be considered delinquent and subject to a delinquency penalty of ten (10) percent for the month of October, plus an additional five (5) percent penalty for each month of delinquency thereafter until paid. However, the total delinquency penalty shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the occupational license fee for the delinquent establishment. 
(b)  Any person engaging in or managing any business, occupation or profession without first obtaining a local occupational license, if required by this chapter, shall be subject to a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the license determined to be due, in addition to any other penalty provided by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1984, § 14-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.053. 
Sec. 16-13. - Exemptions. 
    This chapter shall be subject to the exemptions provided by F.S. § 205.063 et seq. 
(Code 1984, § 14-11) 
Sec. 16-14. - Fire, closing out, auction, bankruptcy, sales. 
(a)  Before any person shall sell or be engaged in the business of selling in the city, goods, wares, merchandise or other personal property, such sales being advertised as bankruptcy, insolvent insurance, assignee, trustee, testator, executor, administrator, receiver, auction, syndicate, railroad or other wrecks, wholesale or manufacturer's or closing out sale, or as goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, such person shall file an application with the tax collector of the city for a license, which application shall be accompanied by an affidavit stating all the facts relating to all the reasons for and the character of such sales so advertised and represented, and including the names of the persons from whom the goods, wares and merchandise or other personal property was obtained, the date of delivering to the person applying for such license and the place from which such goods, wares and merchandise or other personal property was last taken or bought, and all details necessary to exactly locate and fully identify the goods, wares and merchandise or other personal property, and shall further pay to the tax collector as a license for the privilege of selling such goods, wares, merchandise or other personal property the sum prescribed by the license schedule provided for by section 16-10 for each sale. 
(b)  Upon the filing of such application and affidavit and payment of such sum the tax collector shall issue a license to each applicant, but the provisions hereof shall not apply at bona fide sales of general assignees for the benefit of creditors or bona fide trustees selling under power of sale in any deed of trust or mortgage or lien, executors and administrators selling goods of their decedents or to any officer selling the property under legal process, or to regularly licensed auctioneers selling at public outcry in the usual course of their business, or bona fide merchants in selling or disposing of stocks or merchandise who were the original owners of such stocks of merchandise with a license having already been paid for by the merchant prior to the bankruptcy proceedings. 
(c)  Every person, including principals, and their agents, servants or employees who shall sell or engage in the business of selling goods, wares, merchandise or other personal property without having first complied with this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1984, § 14-12) 
Sec. 16-15. - Fee for building industry contractors who maintain offices outside the city. 
    The occupational license fee for all building industry contractors who maintain offices outside the city will be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 99-8, 6-22-1999) 
Sec. 16-16. - Vehicles for hire. 
    Each owner of a business of operating vehicles for hire is required to obtain an occupational license. In order to obtain the occupational license the owner will be required to meet the following criteria: 
(1)  Provide proof of insurance covering workman's' compensation, automobile liability and general liability. 
(2)  Provide copy of a current county occupational license. 
(3)  Provide a list of vehicles to be used. 
(4)  Pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the occupational license and an additional twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each vehicle over one (1). 
(Ord. No. 2001-6, 9-11-2001) 
Sec. 16-17. - Tire dealers. 
    Every business dealing in tires within the City of Pahokee is required to cover any tires stored in the open and not in an enclosed building. The cover must be sufficient to keep rain from collecting in the tires and to shield the tires from the sight of individuals passing by or visiting the site. 
(Ord. No. 2000-5, 4-25-2000) 
Secs. 16-18-16-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WRECKER AND TOWING REGULATIONS 

Secs. 16-21-16-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MEDICAL MARIJUANA[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-07 , §§ 1-4, adopted August 22, 2017, amended the Code by setting out provisions regarding medical marijuana, but did not designate a matter of inclusion, therefore, at the discretion of the editor, these provisions have been included herein. 

Sec. 16-41. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide the City of Pahokee, Florida, with the opportunity to review the impact of recent changes in law, Constitutional amendments, as well as the impact of cannabis dispensing in other jurisdictions, and determine if such dispensing should be permitted and regulated in the City of Pahokee. 
(Ord. No. 2017-07 , § 1, 8-22-2017) 
Sec. 16-42. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words or phrases when used in this article, shall have the means ascribed to them in this article: 
    Cannabis (marijuana) means all parts of any plant of the genus cannabis, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of the plant; and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the plants or its seeds or resin. 
    Cannabis dispensing business or business shall mean a business location offering cannabis for retail sale pursuant to a license to dispense cannabis issued under applicable law, including medical marijuana treatment center dispensary facilities. 
    Chapter 2017-232 shall mean the 2017 Senate Bill 8-A, as signed by the Governor on June 23, 2017. 
    State shall mean the State of Florida. 
    City shall mean the municipal limits of the City of Pahokee, Florida. 
(b)  In addition to the definitions contained in subsection (a), other terms used in this article shall have the meaning ascribed to them in Chapter 2017-232, Florida Law, and are incorporated into this article by this reference. 
(Ord. No. 2017-07 , § 2, 8-22-2017) 
Sec. 16-43. - Moratorium. 
    Beginning on the effective date of this article, a ban is hereby imposed on cannabis dispensing businesses in the City of Pahokee 
(1)  It is unlawful and a violation of this article for any person or entity to open or cause to be opened any medical marijuana treatment center cannabis dispensing business within the City of Pahokee. 
(2)  The city shall not accept, process or approve any application for business tax receipts, licenses, building permits, land use permits, or any development permits concerning or related to a medical marijuana treatment center cannabis dispensing business. 
(3)  This article will be revisited each year. 
(Ord. No. 2017-07 , § 3, 8-22-2017) 
Sec. 16-44. - Penalties. 
    Any person or entity who violates any provision of this article or who fails to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation, per day, or be imprisoned for a period of time not to exceed sixty (60) days. 
(Ord. No. 2017-07 , § 4, 8-22-2017) 
Chapter 17 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes, F.S. Ch. 775 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Adoption of state law misdemeanors. 
    The commission in the city of any misdemeanor set forth in the general laws of the state or any amendment thereto is hereby declared to be a violation of the laws of this city and upon conviction may be punished as set forth for a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1984, § 15-1) 
State Law reference- See Florida Statutes general index under heading "Crimes" for listing of state law misdemeanors. 
Sec. 17-2. - Aid in commission of punishable offenses; accessory before the fact. 
    Whoever aids in commission of any offense punishable by the ordinances of the city or is accessory thereto before the fact, by counseling, hiring, or otherwise procuring such offense to be committed, shall be punished as is provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1984, § 15-2) 
State Law reference- Principals and accessories, F.S. Ch. 777. 
Sec. 17-3. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17-4. - Peeping toms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon the private property of another at night and spy or look into the doors or windows of any structure located on such private property or to otherwise sneak or snoop around such property in a suspicious manner without some lawful purpose or intent. 
(Code 1984, § 15-4) 
Sec. 17-5. - Loitering or prowling. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to loiter or prowl in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. 
(b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such alarm or immediate concern is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstance makes it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern, which would otherwise be warranted, by requesting him to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer did not comply with this procedure, or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person is true and, if believed by the officer at the time, would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(c)  Any law enforcement officer may arrest any suspected loiterer or prowler without a warrant in case delay in processing one will probably enable such suspected loiterer or prowler to escape arrest. 
(Code 1984, § 15-5) 
Sec. 17-6. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17-7. - Aggressive or obstructive panhandling prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions apply in this section: 
    Aggressively beg means to beg with the intent to intimidate another person into giving money or goods. 
    Intimidate means to engage in conduct which would make a reasonable person fearful or feel compelled. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether the actor intends to intimidate another person into giving money or goods are that the actor: (a) touches the person solicited; (b) follows the person solicited and persists in begging after the person solicited has given a negative response; (c) directs profane or abusive language toward the person solicited; or (d) uses violent or threatening gestures or language toward the person solicited. 
    Beg means to ask or solicit for money or goods as a charity, whether by word, bodily gestures, signs, or other means. 
    Obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic means to walk, stand, sit, lie, or place an object in such a manner as to block passage by another person or a vehicle, or to require another person or a driver of a vehicle to take unreasonable evasive action to avoid physical contact. 
    Public place means an area generally visible to public view and includes alleys, bridges, buildings, driveways, parking lots, parks, plazas, sidewalks, and streets open to the general public, including those that serve food or drink or provide entertainment, and the doorways and entrances to buildings or dwellings and the grounds enclosing them. 
    Unreasonable evasive action means causing a vehicle to depart from the lane of traffic in which it is traveling to change lanes, to straddle lanes, or to enter onto a swale to obtain passage. It also means causing a pedestrian to leave the sidewalk on which she or he is traveling or to make contact with a wall or fence bordering the sidewalk. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. A person is guilty of pedestrian interference if, in a public place, he or she intentionally: 
(1)  Obstructs pedestrian or vehicular traffic; or 
(2)  Aggressively begs. 
(c)  Permitted activities. Acts authorized as an exercise of one's constitutional right to picket or to legally protest, and acts authorized by a permit duly issued by a lawful authority shall not constitute obstruction of pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(d)  Penalties. The first violation of this provision shall be punishable by not more than a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and thirty (30) days' incarceration; second and subsequent violations shall be punishable by not more than a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) and sixty (60) days' incarceration. 
(e)  Alternative programs. Nothing herein shall limit the discretion of the police, court personnel, and judges from referring individuals suspected, charged, or convicted of a violation of this provision to treatment programs or facilities as an alternative to prosecution or incarceration, provided that the individual freely consents. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 11-29-1995) 
Sec. 17-8. - Trotlines prohibited. 
(a)  Trotlines (defined as "unmanned fishing line(s) with multiple hooks") and similar devices shall be prohibited in Lake Okeechobee in the areas of the city's campground, picnic area and marina, the area to be defined as that water lying between marker 60 and marker 66 and extending from the shoreline to the outer edge of the Corps of Engineers channel. 
(b)  Any trotlines or similar devices found within said prohibited area may be confiscated and disposed of by the city, as the same constitutes a dangerous condition to persons utilizing Lake Okeechobee in the vicinity of said trotlines. 
(Ord. No. 93-4, §§ 1, 2, 4-27-1993) 
Sec. 17-9. - Malfunctioning fire and burglar alarm systems. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings given below unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Alarm shall mean any device or system of devices designed and used in a building or structure for the detection and alerting of others of unauthorized entry, or any other crime, which emits a sound, signal or message, when activated, including fire alarms. 
    Alarm business shall mean any person engaged in the sale, leasing, installation, maintenance or service of alarm systems or who, in any manner, causes the sale, leasing, installation, maintenance or service alarm systems in or on any building structure or facility. An alarm business shall possess a burglar/fire alarm installation certificate of competency from the county. An alarm business shall also possess an occupational license from the city. 
    Alarm user shall mean any person using an alarm. 
    False alarm shall mean the activation of an alarm through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, the negligence of an alarm user, or any other cause which results in a response by the police/fire when a situation requiring a response by the police/fire wherein it is determined that no criminal activity or attempted criminal activity or fire occurred at the location of the response. It shall be prima facie evidence that no criminal activity or attempted criminal activity or fire occurred if no report stating that the alarm was the result of criminal activity or attempted criminal activity or fire is filed by the police/fire officer who responded to the alarm. 
(b)  False alarms; penalty; review. 
(1)  It is hereby found and determined that false burglar and fire alarms requiring the fire to respond constitute a public nuisance. The alarm user shall be subject to a twenty-five-dollar ($25.00) service fee for each false alarm to which the police or fire respond in excess of two (2) false alarms in a fiscal year of the city. 
(2)  The failure to pay service fees assessed pursuant to this section within thirty (30) days of written notice from the city of the imposition of the fee shall result in an additional fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each false alarm for which a service charge has been assessed pursuant to this section. In the event it shall become necessary for the city to initiate litigation or incur any cost whatsoever in order to collect any delinquent fees pursuant to this section, the alarm user shall be liable for the payment of such cost, including the payment of attorney's fees. 
(3)  An alarm user may seek a review by the fire chief of the determination of the officer responding to the alarm that a false alarm has occurred. To obtain this review, a report written by the alarm user or the alarm business responsible for the maintenance of the alarm, setting forth facts and circumstances tending to show that the activation of the alarm was the result of criminal activity or attempted criminal activity or fire, shall be filed with the police or fire chief within five (5) business days of the date on which the alarm was activated. If the fire chief determines that the facts and circumstances set forth in the report are valid, he shall then excuse the occurrence, and the occurrence shall not constitute a false alarm for the purpose of this section. The fire chief shall issue his written determination within ten (10) working days of receipt of the report from the alarm user or the alarm business. Until such time as the fire chief has made his determination, the occurrence upon which the report is based shall be considered genuine and will not be considered a false alarm. 
(4)  If an alarm user is dissatisfied with the determination made by the fire chief regarding the activation of the alarm, the permit holder may seek a review by the city manager filing a written request with the city within fifteen (15) business days of the date of the determination by the fire chief. The city manager shall determine whether the false alarm occurred. 
(c)  Prohibited alarms. 
(1)  Audible alarms which do not deactivate within fifteen (15) minutes after activation are prohibited. 
(2)  Alarms which automatically dial the police department over lines exclusively used by the public or request emergency service and information are prohibited. 
(3)  Alarms which do not have an auxiliary power supply which activate in the event of a power failure or electrical outage are prohibited. 
(d)  Neither the city manager nor the city or any of its officers and agents shall be under any obligation or duty to an alarm user or to any other person hereunder by reason of this article. The city specifically disclaims liability for any damages which may be caused by failure to respond to an alarm. 
(Ord. No. 93-9, §§ 1-4, 10-26-1999) 
Secs. 17-10-17-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE AND NUISANCE CONTROL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-31. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the City of Pahokee Property Maintenance Code hereinafter referred to as "maintenance code." 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-32. - Scope. 
    The purpose of this code is to protect the public health, safety and welfare by establishing minimum requirements and standards for premises, structures, equipment, and facilities for light, ventilation, space, heating, sanitation, protection from the elements, life safety, safety from fire and other hazards, and for the safe and sanitary maintenance; fixing the responsibility of owners, operators and occupants; regulating the occupancy of structures and premises, and providing for administration, enforcement and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-33. - Intent. 
    This code shall be construed to secure its expressed intent, which is to ensure public health, safety and welfare insofar as they are affected by the continued occupancy and/or maintenance of structures and premises. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-34. - Applicability to existing buildings and structures. 
    The provisions of these maintenance codes apply to every building or structure irrespective of when said building was constructed, altered or repaired. Additionally: 
(1)  If, within any period of twelve (12) months, alterations or repairs costing in excess of fifty (50) percent of the then value of the building are made to an existing building, such building shall be made to conform to the requirements of the City of Pahokee Building Code for new buildings. 
(2)  If an existing building is damaged by fire or otherwise in excess of fifty (50) percent of its then physical value before such damage is repaired, it shall be made to conform to the requirements of the City of Pahokee Building Code for new buildings. 
(3)  If the cost of such alterations or repairs within any twelve-month period or the amount of such damage as referred to in paragraph (2) is more than twenty-five (25) percent but not more than fifty (50) percent of then physical value of the building, the portions to be altered or repaired shall be made to conform to the requirements of the Building Code of the City of Pahokee for new buildings to such extent as the city may determine. 
(4)  Repairs and alterations, not covered by the preceding paragraphs of this article, restoring a building to its condition previous to damage or deterioration, or altering it in conformity with the provisions of the City of Pahokee Building Code or in which manner will not extend or increase an existing conformity or hazard, may be made with the same kind of materials as those of which the building is constructed. 
(5)  For the purpose of these codes the physical value of a building or structure, as hereinafter defined shall be determined by the assessed value of the structure as recorded on the most recent certified tax roll. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-35. - Existing remedies. 
    The provisions in this code shall not be construed to abolish or impair existing remedies of the jurisdiction or its officers or agencies relating to the removal or demolition of any structure that is dangerous, unsafe and unsanitary. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-36. - Workmanship. 
    All repairs, maintenance work, alterations or installations that are caused directly or indirectly by the enforcement of this code shall be executed and installed in a workmanlike manner. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-37. - Application of other codes. 
    Any repairs, additions or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions of all laws, rules and regulations in the City of Pahokee. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-38. - Maintenance. 
    All structures, buildings, equipment, systems, devices and safeguards required by this code or another existing or previous statute or code for the structure or premises when erected or altered shall be maintained in good working order. The requirements of this code are not intended to provide basis for the removal or abrogation of fire protection and safety systems and devices in existing structures. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-39. - Duties and powers of code official. 
(a)  Generally: The code official shall be responsible for the enforcement of all the provisions of this code. 
(b)  Notices and orders: The code official shall issue all necessary notices or orders to ensure compliance with this code. 
(c)  Right of entry: The code official is authorized to enter the structure or premises at reasonable times to inspect subject to constitutional restrictions. If entry is refused or not obtained, the code official is authorized to pursue recourse as provided by law. 
(d)  Access by owner or operator: Every occupant of a structure or premises shall give the owner or operator thereof, or agent or employee, access to any part of the structure or its premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making such inspection, maintenance, repairs or alterations as are necessary to comply with the provisions of this code. 
(e)  Restriction of employees: An official or employee connected with the enforcement of this code, shall not be engaged in, or directly or indirectly connected with, the furnishing of labor, materials, or appliances for the construction, alteration or maintenance to a building, or the preparation of construction documents thereof, unless that person is the owner of the building; nor shall such officer or employee engage in any work that conflicts with official duties or with the interests of the department. 
(f)  Relief from personal responsibility: The code official, officer or employee charged with the enforcement of this code, while acting for this jurisdiction, shall not thereby be rendered liable personally, and is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage accruing to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of official duties. Any suit instituted against an officer or employee because of an act performed by that officer or employee in the lawful discharge of duties and under the provisions of this code shall be defended by the city attorney until final termination of the proceedings. The code official or any subordinate shall not be liable for costs in any action, suit or proceeding that is instituted in pursuance of the provisions of this code, and any officer of the department of building inspection or code enforcement, acting in good faith and without malice, shall be free from all liability for acts performed under any of its provisions or by reason of any act or omission in the performance of official duties in connection herewith. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-40. - Violations. 
(a)  Unlawful acts: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to maintain, fail to maintain, provide, fail to provide, occupy, let to another or occupy or permit another person to occupy any premises, property, structure or equipment regulated by this code, or cause the same to be done, contrary to or in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of this code, or to fail to obey a lawful order of the code official, or to remove or deface a placard or notice posted under the provisions of this code. 
(b)  Enforcement: The provisions of this code shall be enforced by (1) the City of Pahokee Code Enforcement Board and/or special master pursuant to the authority granted by F.S. § 162.01 et seq., as may be amended, (2) the City of Pahokee Commission through its authority to enjoin and restrain any person violating the code. The code enforcement official may pursue these or any other enforcement remedies available to and applicable to the City of Pahokee. 
(c)  Compliance with other ordinances: No certification of compliance with these codes shall constitute a defense against any violations of any other ordinances of the City of Pahokee otherwise applicable to any structure or premises, nor shall any provision of the property maintenance codes relieve any owner or operator from complying with other applicable city ordinances or any official of the City of Pahokee from enforcing such ordinances. 
(d)  Transfer of ownership: It shall be a violation of this code for the owner of any dwelling unit or structure who has received a notice of violation of this code to sell, transfer, mortgage, lease or otherwise dispose of such dwelling or structure to another until the provision of the compliance order or notice of violation has been complied with, or until such owner shall first furnish the grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee a true copy of any compliance order or notice of violation issued by the code official. In addition, the owner shall furnish to the code official a signed notarized statement from the grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee, acknowledging the receipt of such compliance order or notice of violation and fully accepting responsibility without condition for making the corrections or repairs required by the notice of violation. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-41. - Definitions generally. 
(a)  General: Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following terms shall, for the purposes of this code, have meanings shown in this division. 
(b)  Interchangeability: Words stated in the present tense include the future; words stated in the masculine gender include feminine and neuter; the singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular. 
(c)  Terms defined in other codes: Where terms are not defined in this code and are defined in the building, electrical, plumbing or mechanical codes, or the Land Development Code adopted by the City of Pahokee, such terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them as in those codes. 
(d)  Terms not defined: Where terms are not defined, through the methods authorized by this section, such terms shall have ordinary accepted meanings such as the context implies. 
(e)  Parts: Whenever the words "dwelling unit," "dwelling," "premises," "building," "rooming house," "rooming unit" or "story" are stated in this code, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words "or any part thereof." 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 2, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-42. - Definitions of specific terms. 
    Alteration means any change or modification in construction or occupancy. 
    Approved means approved by the code enforcement official. 
    Basement means that portion of a building which is partly or completely below grade. 
    Bathroom means a room containing plumbing fixtures including a bathtub or shower. 
    Boardinghouse means a dwelling, or part thereof, in which lodging is provided by the owner or operator to two (2) or more boarders. 
    Building means any structure built for support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels, or property of any kind. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the words "or part there of." 
    Building code means the Florida Building Code. 
    Code official means the code enforcement officer or any duly authorized representative. 
    Condemn means to adjudge unfit for occupancy. 
    Construction documents means all the written, graphic and pictorial documents prepared or assembled for describing the design, location and physical characteristics of the elements of the project necessary for obtaining a building permit. The construction drawings shall be drawn to an appropriate scale. 
    Exterior property means the open space on the premises and on adjoining property under the control of the owners or operators of such premises. 
    Extermination means the control and elimination of insects, rats or other pests by eliminating their harborage places; by removing or making inaccessible materials that serve as their food; by poison spraying, fumigating, and trapping or by any other approved pest elimination methods. 
    Family means either a single person occupying a dwelling unit and maintaining a household, including not more than one (1) boarder, roomer, or lodger as herein described; or two (2) or more persons related by blood, marriage or adoption occupying a dwelling, living together and maintaining a common household, including not more than one (1) such boarder, roomer, or lodger; or not more than four (4) unrelated persons occupying a dwelling, living together and maintaining a nonprofit housekeeping unit as distinguished from a group occupying a boarding or lodging house, hotel, club or similar dwelling for group use. A common household shall be deemed to exist if all members thereof have access to all parts of the dwelling. 
    Floor area means the total gross area of all habitable space in a building or structure measured to the outside of exterior walls. 
    Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Habitable space means space in a residential structure or unit for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces, and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces. 
    Infestation means the presence, within or contiguous to, a structure, building or premises of insects, rats, vermin or other pests. 
    Inoperable vehicle means one which cannot be driven upon the public streets for reasons including but not limited to being unlicensed, wrecked, abandoned, in a state of disrepair, or in a state of being incapable of being moved under it's own power. 
    Let for occupancy or let means to permit, provide or offer possession or occupancy of a dwelling unit, rooming unit, building, premise or structure by a person who is or is not the legal owner of record thereof, pursuant to a written or unwritten lease, agreement or license, or pursuant to a recorded or unrecorded agreement of contract for the sale of land. 
    Occupancy means the purpose for which a building or portion thereof is utilized or occupied. 
    Occupant means any person living or sleeping in a building; or having possession of a space within a building, including employees. 
    Openable area means that part of a window or door which is available for unobstructed ventilation and which opens directly to the outdoors. 
    Operator means any person who has charge, care or control of a structure or premises which is let or offered for occupancy. 
    Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and any person, group or persons, company, association or corporations in whose name tax bills on the property are submitted. It shall also mean any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others: 
(1)  Shall have legal title to any dwelling or dwelling unit, with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or 
(2)  Shall have charge, care or control of any dwelling or dwelling unit, as owner, executor, executrix, administrator, trustee, guardian of the estate of the owner, mortgagee or vendee in possessions, assignee of rents, lessee, or other person, firm or corporation in control of a building; or their duly authorized agents. Any such person thus representing the actual owner shall be bound to comply with the provision of this ordinance, and of rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, to the same extent as if he were the owner. It is his responsibility to notify the actual owner of the reported infractions of these regulations pertaining to the property which shall apply to the owner. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership or any other group acting as a unit. 
    Plumbing means the practice, materials and fixtures utilized in the installation, maintenance, extension and alteration of all piping, fixtures, appliances and appurtenances in connection with any of the following means sanitary drainage or storm drainage facilities, the venting system and public or private water supply systems, within or adjacent to any building, structure, or conveyance; also the practice and materials used in the installation, maintenance, extension or alteration of the storm water, liquid waste, or sewage, and water supply systems of any premises to their connection with any point of public disposal. 
    Plumbing fixture means a receptacle or device which is either permanently or temporarily connected to the water distribution system of the premises, and demands a supply of water there from; or discharges waste water, liquid-borne waste materials, or sewage either directly or indirectly to the drainage system of the premises; or which requires both a water supply connection and a discharge to the drainage system of the premises. 
    Premises means a lot, plot or parcel of land including any structures thereon. 
    Registered design professional means an architect or engineer, registered or licensed to practice professional architecture or engineering, as defined by the statutory requirements of the professional registration laws in the State of Florida. 
    Repair means the reconstruction or renewal of any part of any existing building for purpose of its maintenance. 
    Rubbish means combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage, including; paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass crockery, trash and debris and other similar materials and shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible materials. 
    Structure means that which is built or constructed or a portion thereof, including the term building. 
    Tenant means a person, corporation, partnership or group, whether or not the legal owner of record, occupying a building or portion thereof as a unit. 
    Toilet room means a room containing a water closet or urinal but not a bathtub or shower. 
    Ventilation means the natural or mechanical process of supplying conditioned or unconditioned air to, or removing such air from, any space. 
    Workmanlike means executed in a skilled manner; e.g., generally plumb, level, square, in line, undamaged and without marring adjacent work. 
    Yard means an open space on the same lot with a structure. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 3, 11-23-2004) 
Secs. 17-43-17-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 17-71. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this division shall govern the minimum conditions and the responsibilities of persons for maintenance of structures, equipment and exterior property. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 4, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-72. - Responsibility. 
    The owner of the premises shall maintain the structures and exterior property in compliance with these requirements, except as provided for a person shall not occupy as owner-occupant or permit another person to occupy premises which do not comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 4, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-73. - Vacant structures and land. 
(a)  All vacant structures and premises thereof or vacant land shall be maintained in a clean, safe, secure and sanitary condition as provided herein so as not to cause a deteriorating problem or adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  The exterior of all vacant structures shall be maintained in a manner required of occupied structures as provided in this code. Window areas shall be maintained free of broken glass, exterior doors shall be water- and weather-tight, walls and roof areas shall be maintained in a clean, safe and intact condition, and water- and weather-tight. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 4, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-74. - Exterior property areas. 
(a)  Sanitation: All exterior property and premises shall be maintained in a clean, safe and sanitary condition. The occupant shall keep that part of the exterior property which such occupant occupies or controls in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(b)  Sidewalks and driveways: All sidewalks, walkways, stairs, driveways, parking lots, parking spaces and similar areas shall be kept in a proper state of repair, and maintained free from hazardous conditions. 
(c)  Weeds: All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of twelve (12) inches. All noxious weeds shall be prohibited. This term shall include cultivated flowers and gardens, or native vegetation. 
(d)  Accessory structures: All accessory structures, including detached garages, carports, fences, walls, and swimming pools shall be maintained structurally sound and in good repair. 
(e)  Water clarity in swimming pools: Water clarity shall be maintained. When standing at the pool's edge at the deep end, the deepest portion of the swimming pool floor shall be visible. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 4, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-75. - Exterior of structure or building. 
(a)  General: The exterior of a structure shall be maintained in good repair, structurally sound and sanitary so as not to pose a threat to the public health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  Exterior painting: All wood and metal surfaces including but not limited to, window frames, doors, door frames, cornices, porches and trim shall be maintained in good condition. Peeling, flaking and chipped paint shall be eliminated and surfaces repainted. 
(c)  Street numbers: One (1) address sign shall be required for each principal building or use on premises showing only the numerical address designation on the premises which they are maintained or multi-unit buildings, which utilize a roadside marquee/signboard, the full building address shall be posted on such marquee/signboard. The address shall be posted in a color contrasting that of the marquee/signboard or building a minimum six (6) inches for residential and eight (8) inches for commercial structure, and of sufficient size to be plainly visible and legible from the roadway. When the building utilizes multiple addresses, such multiple occupant mercantile buildings, the address range shall be posted as indicated above. Signs shall be plainly visible from the street or right-of-way providing access to the lot. This requirement shall apply to all new and existing structures. 
(d)  Structural members: All structural members shall be maintained free from deterioration, and shall be capable of supporting the imposed dead and live loads. 
(e)  Foundation walls: All foundation walls shall be maintained plumb and free from open cracks and breaks and shall be kept in such condition so as to prevent entry of rats. 
(1)  Skirting: Existing skirting shall be maintained free from broken or missing sections, pieces or cross members. Skirting shall be securely attached and sized from the ground to the lower outside perimeter of the structure. 
(2)  Replacement skirting: Replacement or new skirting shall be constructed or materials intended for exterior use and properly sized and mounted to prevent free access to the crawl space of the structure. 
(f)  Exterior walls: All exterior walls shall be free from holes, breaks, loose or rotting materials; and maintained weatherproof and properly surface coated where required to prevent deterioration. 
(g)  Roofs and drainage: The roof and flashing shall be sound, tight and not have defects that admit rain. Roof drainage shall be adequate to prevent dampness or deterioration in the walls or interior portion of the structure. Roof drains, gutters and down spouts shall be maintained in good repair and free from obstructions. Roof water shall not be discharged in a manner that creates an adjacent public nuisance. 
(h)  Decorative features: All cornices, belt courses, terra cotta trim, wall facings and similar decorative features shall be maintained in good repair with proper anchorage and in a safe condition. 
(i)  Overhang extensions: All canopies, marquees, signs, metal awnings, fire escapes, stand pipes, exhaust ducts and similar overhang extensions shall be maintained in good repair and be properly anchored so as to be kept in a sound condition. When required, all exposed surfaces of metal or wood shall be protected from the elements and against decay or rust by periodic application of weather-coating materials, such as paint or similar surface treatment. 
(j)  Stairways, decks, porches and balconies: Every exterior stairway, deck, porch, balcony, railings and all other appurtenances attached thereto, shall be maintained structurally sound, in good repair, with proper anchorage and capable of supporting the imposed loads. 
(k)  Chimneys and towers: All chimneys, cooling towers, smoke stacks, and similar appurtenances shall be maintained structurally safe and sound, and in good repair. 
(l)  Handrails and guards: Every handrail and guard shall be firmly fastened and capable of supporting normally imposed loads and shall be maintained in good condition. 
(m)  Windows and doorframes: Every window, door and frame shall be kept in sound condition, good repair and weather-tight. Every window, other than a fixed window, shall be easily openable and capable of being held in position by window hardware. 
(n)  Doors: All exterior doors and hardware shall be maintained in good condition. Locks at all entrances to dwelling units, rooming units and guestrooms shall tightly secure the door. Every dwelling unit shall have a safe, unobstructed means of egress with a minimum height of seven (7) feet. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 4, 11-23-2004) 
Sec. 17-76. - Interior of structure or building. 
(a)  General: The interior of a structure and equipment herein shall be maintained in good repair, structurally sound and in a sanitary condition. Every occupant shall keep that part of the structure which such occupant occupies or controls in a clean and sanitary condition. Every owner of a structure containing a rooming house, a hotel, a dormitory, two (2) or more dwelling units or two (2) or more nonresidential occupancies, shall maintain, in a clean and sanitary condition, the shared or public areas of the structure and exterior property. 
(b)  Structural members: All structural members shall be maintained structurally sound, and capable of supporting imposed loads.
