(e)  The posting shall be placed on the interior of a window facing the street to the front of the property so that it is visible from the street, or secured to the exterior of the building/structure facing the street to the front of the property so that it is visible from the street or if no such area exists, on a stake of sufficient size to support the posing in a location that is at all times visual from the street to the front of the property but not readily accessible to vandals. Exterior posting shall be constructed of and printed with weather-resistant materials. 
(f)  Failure of the mortgagee and/or property owner of record to properly inspect and secure the property, and post and maintain the signage noted in this section, is a violation of this article and shall result in the issuance of a notice of violation by a code compliance officer. Pursuant to a finding and determination by the special magistrate, the city may take the necessary action to ensure compliance with this section, and place a lien on the property and assign it as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2010-07, § 2(17-192), 7-13-2010) 
Sec. 17-283. - Opposing, obstructing enforcement officer; penalty. 
    Whoever opposes, obstructs or resists any enforcement officer, or any person authorized by the city, in the discharge of duties as provided in this article, upon conviction may be sanctioned as provided in the Code of Ordinances of the city, or F.S. ch. 162. 
(Ord. No. 2010-07, § 2(17-193), 7-13-2010) 
Sec. 17-284. - Immunity of enforcement officer. 
    Any enforcement officer, or any person authorized by the city to enforce this article, shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for reasonable, good faith entry or trespass upon real property while in the discharge of duties imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-07, § 2(17-194), 7-13-2010) 
Sec. 17-285. - Additional authority. 
    The code enforcement administrator shall have authority to require the mortgagee and/or owner of record of any property affected by this article to require an on-site security guard. Failure to comply with the terms of this article shall constitute a continuing public nuisance. The city shall have the authority to promptly abate the public nuisance, in whole or in part, at the expense of the mortgagee or other responsible party. 
(Ord. No. 2010-07, § 2(17-195), 7-13-2010) 
Sec. 17-286. - Supplemental provisions. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the city from enforcing its codes by any other means, including, but not limited to, injunction, abatement or as otherwise provided by code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-07, § 2(17-196), 7-13-2010) 
Chapter 18 - PAHOKEE HARBOR[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Dumping garbage and trash in waterways prohibited, § 11-12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Florida boat registration and safety law, F.S. Ch. 327; local regulations qualified, F.S. § 327.60. 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Boat means any craft, whether propelled by mechanical means or otherwise, used in, on or about the water, as a means of locomotion. 
    Pahokee Harbor means the area as defined in that certain permit from the Trustees of the Internal Improvement Fund of the State of Florida to the city, as recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court, Palm Beach County, Florida, Clerk's File No. 3192, filed November 30, 1956. 
(Code 1984, § 16-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-2. - Prohibited acts. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Swim within Pahokee Harbor, except for the rescue of another person or repair or salvage of a boat; 
(2)  Water ski or jet ski within Pahokee Harbor; 
(3)  Operate any boat within Pahokee Harbor at a rate of speed in excess of four (4) miles per hour; 
(4)  Operate any boat within Pahokee Harbor within fifty (50) feet of any existing structure of the harbor, except when engaged in docking; 
(5)  Have possession of any glass beverage container on the breakwater of Pahokee Harbor; 
(6)  Operate any bicycle or motor vehicle upon the existing dock or breakwater of Pahokee Harbor except when engaged in authorized servicing, maintenance, or the loading or unloading of any boat. 
(Code 1984, § 16-2) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles generally, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 18-3. - Special permits. 
    The city commission may issue special temporary permits from time to time for the holding of water shows, boat races or other public exhibitions allowing the following which shall not be deemed a violation of this chapter when performed pursuant thereto: 
(1)  Swimming within Pahokee Harbor; 
(2)  Waterskiing or jet skiing within Pahokee Harbor; 
(3)  Operation of a boat in excess of four (4) miles per hour. 
(Code 1984, § 16-3) 
Sec. 18-4. - Storage or abandonment of boats and boat trailers in Hoover Levee right-of-way. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to store, abandon or allow to remain out of the water in an area consisting of the United States Hoover Levee right-of-way between the existing westerly fence line of the Pahokee State Park recreation area and easterly of a line located parallel to and twenty (20) feet easterly of the point where the easterly line of the existing wooden T Dock joints the land area, any boat, or boat trailer, for a period of longer than forty-eight (48) hours. 
(b)  Any police officer of this city is hereby authorized to provide for the removal of any such boat, or boat trailer found to be in violation of this section to the nearest garage, or other place of safety, cost of such removal to be a lien against the property. 
(Code 1984, § 16-4) 
Chapter 19 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; planning and zoning division, § 2-104; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; land development code, Ch. 14; mobile homes and recreational vehicles, Ch. 15; public improvements, Ch. 20; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; subdivisions, Ch. 23; utilities, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- State comprehensive planning, F.S. § 23.011 et seq.; local government comprehensive planning and land development regulation act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Adoption of comprehensive plan. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq., the city commission hereby adopts the comprehensive plan of the city consisting of a future land use element, traffic circulation element, housing element, sanitary sewer, solid waste, drainage, potable water and natural groundwater aquifer recharge element, coastal management element, conservation element, recreation and open space element, intergovernmental coordination element, and a capital improvements element. A copy of each of the elements is attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived, and each element is adopted by reference and made a part of this section the same as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1984, § 17-2; Ord. No. 89-12, § 1, 9-11-1989) 
Secs. 19-2-19-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ZONING/ADJUSTMENT/ PLANNING BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 98-7, adopted August 25, 1998, has been treated by the editor as amending the Code by repealing former Art. II, §§ 19-26-19-32, and adding a new Art. II, § 19-26. Former Art. II pertained to the city planning board, and derived from the Code of 1984, §§ 17-16-17-22. 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 2-126 et seq.; review of preliminary plan of subdivision by planning board, § 23-6. 

Sec. 19-26. - Created; composition. 
    The board of adjustment and the planning and zoning board are combined to form the zoning/adjustment/planning board. The zoning/adjustment/planning board will assume the functions of both boards as previously set forth. 
    The terms of the board members shall be staggered and set forth in the following manner: One (1) member shall be appointed for a term of (1) year; two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years; and two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. In addition two (2) alternates shall be appointed for a period of three (3) years each. After the initial appointments, successive appoints shall be for a period of three (3) years, except where an appointment is made to fill a vacancy, in which case such appointment shall be for the balance of the term of the member in which the vacancy occurred. 
    The main duties of the board will be to address zoning issues, site plans, and variances. The detailed outline of duties is found in the land development regulations and includes the duties designated for both boards. 
(Ord. No. 98-7, 8-25-1998) 
Chapter 20 - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances relating to local improvements and assessments therefor saved from repeal, § 1-7(10); administration, Ch. 2; planning, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; subdivisions, Ch. 23; utilities, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Municipal bond authority, F.S. § 166.101 et seq.; supplemental and alternative method of making local improvements, F.S. Ch. 170; municipal public works, F.S. Ch. 180. 

Sec. 20-1. - "Municipal improvements" defined. 
    As used in this chapter, the term "municipal improvement" shall be construed to mean the opening, widening, laying out, paving, grading, extending, digging, construction, alteration or discontinuation of any park, street, highway, building or repairing a sidewalk, foot pavement, alley or other way, ditch, drain or gutter, or the laying, construction, repairing, changing, vacating, enlarging, diminishing or improving of any sewer within the city. 
(Code 1984, § 18-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-2. - Authority of city. 
(a)  Improvements designated; cost; condemnation; rights and duties of property owners; assessments; contracts; protests; suits in equity; liens. The city shall have power to open, establish, abolish, alter, extend, widen, grade, regrade, pave, repave, or otherwise improve, clean and keep in repair or rebuild streets, thoroughfares and construct, erect and keep in repair and rebuild bridges, bulkheads, seawalls, jetties, culverts, gutters, curbs, sewers and drains; to regulate and provide for the construction, preservation and repair of streets, avenues, alleys, sidewalks, foot pavements and other public ways and thoroughfares and paving and repairing the same; to provide for the protection and preservation of any street, road or boulevard, built or constructed for use of the general public along the shore of Lake Okeechobee from erosion of the waters of Lake Okeechobee, by the construction and maintenance of seawalls, bulkheads and jetties along such boulevard; to provide for the construction of sewers, septic tanks, complete sanitary sewerage disposal plants or works and drains and for keeping the same in repair; to acquire by purchase or gift within or without the city limits, land for the erection of a garbage disposal plant, and to provide for the cost of the same, either out of the regular funds of the city or by issuance of bonds; to provide for a uniform character of sidewalks which shall be built upon a grade established by the city; to take and appropriate private grounds, in the manner and form provided by law for condemnation for widening streets or parts thereof, or for extending the same, or for laying out new streets, avenues, alleys, parks and promenades; to grant the right-of-way through the streets, alleys, avenues and public grounds of the city for the use of public conveyances or railways, but the owner of property abutting thereon shall not thereby be deprived of any right he may have to claim any damage that he may receive by reason of such right-of-way; to require owners of property or their agents to keep their lots, tracts, or parcels of land free and clean of weeds, brush, undergrowth, trash, filth, garbage or other refuse or in case of their failure to do so, the city may remove or cause the removal of such weeds, brush, undergrowth, trash, filth, garbage or other refuse, and may charge and assess the expense thereof against the property so cleaned and improved; to provide for the care and protection of trees, shrubs and flowers in the public streets, parks and grounds; to impose penalties on the owner or occupant of or agent for the owner of any sidewalk, house or other structure, place or thing which may be dangerous or detrimental to the inhabitants of the city or dangerous or detrimental to their property, unless after due notice the same is removed or remedied in accordance with the requirements of the city. Whenever the city commission shall decide to open, establish, abolish, alter, extend, widen, grade, fill in, clear, clean, pave, construct, reconstruct, repair or otherwise improve any street, avenue, alley, or other way or thoroughfare or to build, construct, reconstruct, repair or improve any sewer, septic tank, sanitary disposal plants or works, drainage ditch within the city, and defray the whole or any part of the expense thereof by special assessment, the city commission shall so declare by resolution stating the nature of the proposed improvement, designating the streets to be so improved, what part or portion of the expense thereof is to be paid by special assessment, the manner in which the assessment shall be made, when the assessments are to be paid, what part, if any, shall be apportioned to be paid from the general improvement fund of the municipality, and the resolution shall also designate the lands upon which the special assessment shall be levied; and in describing the lands it shall be sufficient to describe the lots and lands, deemed to be specially benefited abutting upon and contiguous to the contemplated improvement, as: "All lots and lands adjoining and contiguous or bounding and abutting upon such improvement." Such resolution shall also state the total estimated cost of the improvement. Notice of the adoption of the resolution shall be given by causing to be published a copy of the resolution one (1) time in a newspaper of general circulation published in the city, and if there is no newspaper published in the city then in a newspaper of general circulation published in the county in which the city is located. The city commission shall cause the work and improvements to be done by contract or otherwise, and the city commission may, in its discretion, enter into separate contracts for any grading, filling, clearing, cleaning, curbing or paving or for any portion of either; or the city commission may, in its discretion, perform all or any portion of any public work under its own supervision under a foreman or other agency, employing such labor as may seem necessary, and not let the work under contract, as may in its opinion best serve the interest of the public. When such work has been completed, the city commission may pay the expense of the work out of any funds belonging to the city available for such purpose, and the city commission may assess the cost of such work or such portion thereof as it may determine, upon the property benefited by the improvement, or upon the abutting property in proportion to frontage. Any lot, or parcel of land on a corner may be assessed for its proportionate share of the improvement in the crossing or street adjacent to the corner. After the completion of any work provided for in this section, the commission shall adopt a resolution assessing the cost of the work or such portion thereof as it may determine, against the property benefited thereby, or against the abutting property in proportion to the frontage, or as above stated at a corner or a crossing; and thereupon the commission shall cause to be published two (2) times successively, once each week, in a newspaper of general circulation, published in the city, and if there is no newspaper published in the city then in a newspaper of general circulation published in the county, a notice of the completion of the work, which notice shall contain a description of each tract of land assessed, the amount of the assessment against such tract, the dates when the assessment will be due, which shall not exceed ten (10) years, and the rate of interest which the assessments bear. In such notice, the name of the owners or such other persons or corporations interested in any lands need not appear, but only a sufficient description of the lot, parcel or tract of land to make it capable of identification shall be necessary. Such notice shall fix not less than thirty (30) days from the posting of the notice when the commission will hear complaints of the owners or other persons or corporations interested in such lands against the amount or justice of the assessment. The notice may be in substantially the following form and when substantially in such form shall be sufficient, to wit: 
    Notice is hereby given that the City of Pahokee, Florida, has completed (here state the general nature of the work, such as the paving or repairing of a street within certain limits or a very brief, concise description of the improvement) and has assessed (here state proportion assessed) the expense of the improvement against the abutting property (or the property benefited, as the case may be). The following are the assessments made by the City Commission of the City of Pahokee against such tract of land; (one-third, all, or one-fourth as the case may be) (stating the time when due) of each of the assessments will be due on ____________ (insert here maturity date of first payment); ____________ of each assessment will be due on ____________ ; and ____________ of each assessment will be due on ____________ . Such assessments will bear interest at the rate of ____________ percent per annum from the ____________ day of ____________ , payable annually. The City Commission will meet at the City Hall at ____________ o'clock ____________ M. on the ____________ to hear complaints against the justice or amount of such assessments. 
The notice may be signed by the city clerk or by the presiding officer of the city commission. All protests or complaints against any of such assessments shall be made in writing and filed with the city clerk prior to such meeting, and shall specifically state the grounds of the complaint or protest. The owner or any person or corporation interested in any land against which such assessment is made may appear before the commission at the meeting and urge before the commission the grounds of the protest or complaint stated in the written protest or complaint above provided for, and after hearing and considering the same the commission may if it deems it just or right, decrease the amount of any such assessment, but no assessment shall be increased against any land after the assessment has been once made. Any person or corporation owning or interested in any land against which any such assessment had been made, who shall fail to file the written protest or complaint within the time, as provided for in this section, shall be deemed and held to have consented to the assessment; and any such person owning or interested in any land against which any such assessment is made, who shall present his written complaint or protest as above provided and who is dissatisfied with the action of the city commission at the meeting may, within sixty (60) days after the meeting, file a suit in equity to enjoin the collection or enforcement of the assessment; and unless the suit is filed within such time the person shall not thereafter be held in any proceeding in any court either at law or in equity as plaintiff or defendant to question or contest the legality of any such assessment. Such assessment shall constitute and be a lien against the land against which the assessment is made from the date of the meeting of the city commission held to hear complaints against the assessment, which lien shall be prior and superior in dignity to all other liens thereon, except liens for taxes; and the amount of such assessment shall bear interest from the date of the making of such assessment, at a rate to be fixed by the city commission, which shall not exceed eight (8) percent per annum. 
(b)  City improvement lien book. The city commission shall cause to be prepared and kept by the city clerk a city improvement lien book, in which shall be entered the date of the making of each assessment, the amount of the assessment against each lot, parcel or other tract of land, the general purpose for which the assessment was made, and such other information as may be deemed advisable by the city commission. The entry in the city improvement lien book shall be and constitute notice to the public of the lien against such lands, and no other record or notice thereof shall be necessary to any person. 
(c)  Payment of assessments and liens. The owner or any other person interested in any land against which such assessment is made may pay the lien and have it satisfied by the tax collector at any time prior to suit thereon by paying the amount of such assessment and the interest thereon to the date of such payment. In case of the failure of any person owning such lands to pay the assessments for improvements as provided in this section during the time the tax books are open for the payment of the same, the city clerk shall place on the books the whole amount of the assessment, and the same shall become immediately due and payable, and no city taxes or other liens on the property shall be paid until the full amount of such assessment is paid to the tax collector. 
(d)  Certificates of indebtedness. The city commission may at any time after such assessments are made, issue and dispose of certificates of indebtedness upon the assessments under the provisions of F.S. Ch. 170. 
(e)  Installment paying. The assessments may be made due and payable in such installments and at such times as the city commission may by resolution prescribe. 
(f)  Enforcement of lien. Any lien provided for in this section may be enforced and collected by suit at law or in equity, upon failure to promptly pay the lien and assessment, or any installment thereof, or the city may maintain a personal action against the owner to recover the same, or it may enforce its lien and maintain its personal action at the same time, until actually paid the amount due; and in any suit by the city, either at law or in equity, for the collection of the amount of such lien, the city shall be entitled to recover a reasonable attorney's fee, together with the costs of the proceedings, which attorney's fees and costs shall also become a lien upon such lands. 
(g)  Landfill; drainage. If at any time the city commission shall deem it necessary or expedient for the preservation of the public health, or for any other reason, that any lot, parcel or tract of vacant land then lying and being within the city, which may be lower than any street, avenue or public way adjoining the same or the grade established therefor, or which may be subject to overflow or to the accumulation of water thereon, should be filled in or ditched or drained, the commission shall have the power to direct and require the owner of the lot, parcel or piece of vacant land to fill in the same to such grade or ditch or drain the lot, parcel or tract of vacant land, in such manner as the commission shall direct. Such notice shall be given by a resolution of the commission, a copy of which shall be served in like manner as specified in this section. If the owner of the lots or tracts of land shall not within such time as such resolution shall prescribe, fill in, ditch or drain the lot, parcel or tract of vacant land as therein directed, it shall be lawful for the commission to cause the same to be done, and to pay therefor and to charge, assess and collect the expense thereof against the lot, parcel or tract of land and against the owner thereof. All of the provisions mentioned in this section relative to the making of the assessment and proceedings subsequent thereto, decreasing the amount of the assessment, contesting the legality of the assessment, acquisition by the city of a lien and the effect thereof, rate of interest, entry in the city improvement lien book, effect of such entry, payment of lien, issuance of certificates of indebtedness, the enforcement and collection of the lien and attorney's fees, shall be applicable to and shall be followed in making and enforcing the assessments authorized by this subsection. 
(h)  Abutting owners may be required to make designated improvements. The commission may adopt a resolution directing and requiring the owner of any lot, parcel or tract of land fronting or abutting on any street, avenue, alley or other public way to construct, build or repair a sidewalk, foot pavement, curb, or gutter or either one (1) or more of such improvements thereon, to be built in front of such abutting property or in front of the lot a corner of which lies between two (2) streets, and upon a grade, and of such materials, width, and other dimensions and in such manner, as the commission shall direct. The resolution shall fix the time within which the work shall be done. If the owners of the lots or tracts of land shall not, within the time fixed in the resolution, build, construct, or repair such sidewalk or foot pavement, curb or gutter, or either one (1) or more of the improvements, in the manner and as directed in the resolution, the commission may cause the same to be done, and pay therefor, and charge, assess and collect the expense thereof against such lot, parcel or tract of land, and against the owner thereof. All the provisions in this section relating to the making of the assessment and proceedings subsequent thereto, notice to hear complaints and action thereon, and the effect thereof, decreasing the amount of the assessment, contesting the legality of the assessment, acquisition by the city of a lien and the effect thereof, rate of interest, entry in the city improvement lien book, effect of such entry, payment of lien, issuance of certificates of indebtedness, the enforcement and collection of the lien and attorney's fees, shall be applicable to and shall be followed in making and enforcing the assessment authorized by this subsection. 
(i)  Removal of brush, weeds, garbage, trash, etc. If at any time the commission shall deem it necessary or expedient for the preservation of public health or safety, or for the general welfare of the city or for any good reason, that any owner of land or riparian rights within the city should remove therefrom all brush, weeds, palmetto, dead or dying trees, stumps, roots, obnoxious growth or thing of any kind, filth, garbage, trash, debris, decayed or decaying buildings or structures, ruins of any kind, buildings, docks, wharves or other structures in a falling or dangerous condition, the commission shall have the power to direct and require the owner of such land or riparian right to remove it. Such notice shall be given by a resolution of the commission, a copy of which shall be served in like manner as specified in this section. If the owner of the land or riparian rights shall not, within such time as such resolution shall prescribe, which shall not be less than thirty (30) days, remove from such land or riparian rights the thing directed and required to be removed, it shall be lawful for the commission to cause it to be removed, and to pay therefor, and to charge, assess and collect the expense thereof, as a lien against the land or riparian rights or as a claim against the owner thereof. All the provisions in this section relative to the making of the assessment and proceedings subsequent thereto, notices to hear complaints and action thereon and the effect thereof, decreasing the amount of the assessment, contesting the legality of the assessment, acquisition by the city of a lien and the effect thereof, rate of interest, entry in the city improvement lien book, effect of such entry, payment of the lien, issuance of certificates of indebtedness, the enforcement and collection of the lien and attorney's fees, shall be applicable to and may be followed in making and enforcing the assessments authorized by the foregoing subsection. 
(j)  Alternate procedure for notice. As an alternative procedure for notice to owners as provided in this section the city commission may give notice by mailing a copy of the resolution by registered mail to such owner as shown by the last tax assessment roll at his last known address and in like manner a copy of the notice of completion of the work. 
(Code 1984, § 18-2) 
Sec. 20-3. - Contracts for construction of municipal improvements. 
    The city is authorized to enter into and agree upon the terms of contracts with private parties for the installation, accomplishment or construction of municipal improvements. In such cases such private parties may do all of the work in accordance with specifications prescribed by the city, or in the alternative, may contract to do certain specified parts of the work to be done in conjunction with the city itself. 
(Code 1984, § 18-3) 
Sec. 20-4. - Financing municipal improvements. 
    In consideration of municipal improvements to be done by such private parties the city may sell or agree to sell to such private contracting parties any or all of the municipal improvement liens assessed by the city against abutting property for benefits to such property resulting from the municipal improvements so constructed. Such liens shall be evidenced by special assessment lien certificates and shall be assigned by the city without recourse against the city in the event of failure of payment. Such liens may be enforced by the party to whom assigned or anyone holding under him as any other liens are enforced in equity, or the city may agree to enforce such liens for and in behalf of the holder thereof. 
(Code 1984, § 18-4) 
Sec. 20-5. - Petition for improvements; costs. 
    The city commission shall, upon petition signed by a majority of the residents of any block on a street requesting the paving, repaving, grading or oiling of same, grant such request within a reasonable time, charging therefor the cost of such work two-thirds to the property on each side of the street at the same rate per foot and one-third to be borne out of the general fund. This same rule shall apply as to lighting, other than that regularly provided. 
(Code 1984, § 18-5) 
Chapter 21 - SOLICITORS, PEDDLERS AND ITINERANT VENDORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 21-1-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 16. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler means any person, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance. Anyone who solicits orders and, as a separate transaction, makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article shall be deemed a peddler, including: 
(1)  Stationary peddler. The term "stationary peddler" means someone who uses the location for sale of goods that extend beyond the type of personal goods sold at yard sales. 
(2)  Solicitor. The term "solicitor" means any individual, whether resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, taking or attempting to take orders for sales of goods, wares, and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or not. Such definition shall include any person who, for himself or for another person hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop, or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
(3)  Transient peddler. The term "transient peddler" means any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building; structure; motor vehicle; tent; railroad boxcar, boat; public room in a hotel, lodginghouse, apartment, shop; or any street, alley, or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at a public auction. 
(Code 1984, § 19-16; Ord. No. 2000-2, 4-11-2000; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-27. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The license required under this article shall be provided to any law enforcement or code enforcement officer with jurisdiction in the city upon request. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall be enforceable by any law enforcement or code enforcement officer with jurisdiction in the city. 
(Code 1984, § 19-26; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-28. - Use of public streets by peddlers. 
(a)  No peddler shall have exclusive right to any location in the public right-of-way. 
(b)  No peddler shall he be permitted a stationary location, on any public property. 
(c)  No peddler shall be permitted to operate in any congested area where his operations might impede traffic. 
(d)  A peddler in a stationary location may not operate more than two (2) days a week. 
(e)  A peddler in a stationary location must have written permission from the location's property owner. 
(f)  Stationary peddlers shall only operate on locations zoned for commercial activity and are restricted to daylight hours (sunrise to sunset). 
(Code 1984, §§ 19-27, 19-34(3); Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-29. - Use of loud noises and sound amplifying devices by peddlers. 
    No peddler shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell or use any sound device, including any sound amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks, or other places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom to be capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys, parks or other public places. 
(Code 1984, § 19-34(2); Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Secs. 21-30-21-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IDENTIFICATION CARD AND LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 21-41. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a peddler within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining an identification card and license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1984, § 19-17; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-42. - Penalty. 
    Any person conducting business as a peddler without an identification card and license, or operating in violation of any provision of this Division, shall be punished upon conviction by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment in County Jail for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment for each violation. 
(Code 1984, § 19-17; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-43. - Garage/yard sale exception. 
(a)  Garage/yard sales may only occur on Saturdays, between the hours of 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Only garage/yard sales conducted by the owner or occupant of a residential unit on the owner's or occupant's residential property are permitted. The operator of the garage/yard sales shall not allow any signs or goods to remain outside on the yard or on the property during the hours the garage/yard sale is not operating. All property must be left in a clean and presentable manner with no evidence that a garage/yard sale operated at that location. 
(b)  A permit must be obtained from City Hall prior to each sale. 
(c)  Only one (1) sign will be permitted on the premises of a garage/yard sale. 
(Code 1984, § 19-17; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-44. - Application. 
(a)  Applicants for identification cards and licenses required by this division must file with the city clerk a sworn written application in duplicate, on forms to be furnished by the city clerk, which give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and goods to be sold; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials signed by the employer recognizing the employment; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the vehicle, together with the license number or other means of identification; 
(7)  The place the goods or services proposed to be sold, or any ordered for future delivery are manufactured or produced, and the proposed method of delivery; 
(8)  Two (2) photographs) of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be not larger than two (2) inches by two (2) inches and not smaller than one (1) inch by one (1) inch, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(9)  A criminal records review provided by the Sheriff of Palm Beach, current within the last thirty (30) days. 
(b)  At the time of filing the application a fee in the amount of $150.00 per year shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of investigation of the facts required by this section. If a peddler obtained a license from the city within the twelve (12) months prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived, the license fee shall be waived for the first renewal after the adoption of this division. 
(Code 1984, § 19-18; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-45. - Investigation of character of applicant. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for the identification card and the license required by this division. The clerk shall review the application to determine the applicant's qualifications under this division. 
(b)  All individuals issued an identification card and license must be of good moral character. Good moral character shall be construed to mean the propensity on the part of the applicant to serve the public in a fair and honest manner. 
(c)  A judgment of guilt in a criminal prosecution or a judgment in a civil action shall not be used, in and of itself, as proof of a person's lack of good moral character. It may be used as evidence in the determination, and when so used the person shall be notified and shall be permitted to rebut the evidence by showing that at the current time he has the ability to and is likely to serve the public in a fair, honest and open manner, that he is rehabilitated, or that the substance of the former offense is not reasonably related to the occupation or profession for which he seeks to be licensed. 
(d)  The following criminal records shall not be used, examined or requested by the city in a determination of moral character: 
(1)  Records of an arrest not followed by a conviction; 
(2)  Records of a conviction which has been reversed or vacated, including the arrest records relevant to that conviction; 
(3)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor or a felony unrelated to the person's likelihood to serve the public in a fair, honest, and open manner; 
(e)  When a person is found to be unqualified for a license because of a lack of good moral character, or similar criteria, the person shall be furnished by the clerk a statement denying the license. The statement shall contain a record of the evidence upon which the determination was based. The person shall be entitled to appeal the decision to the city commission. 
(Code 1984, § 19-19; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-46. - Issuance. 
    If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant for the identification card and the license required by this division are found to be satisfactory, the clerk shall approve the identification card and license upon payment of fees established by the city commission. 
(Code 1984, § 19-20; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-47. - Content of identification card; clerk's record of licenses. 
    The identification card issued pursuant to this division shall contain the signatures of the applicant and shall show the name, address, a photograph, a general description and the fingerprint of the right index finger of the applicant. The clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1984, § 19-21; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-48. - Exhibition. 
    Solicitors and peddlers are required to have in their possession their licenses and identification cards. 
(Code 1984, § 19-22; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-49. - Expiration. 
    Annual licenses and identification cards issued pursuant to this division shall expire on January 1 of the year in which issued. Licenses and identification cards issued for shorter periods shall expire on the date specified in the license. 
(Code 1984, § 19-23; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-50. - Revocation-Grounds. 
    Identification cards and licenses issued pursuant to this division may be revoked by code enforcement special magistrate, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for a license; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business as solicitor or peddler; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
(5)  Conducting the business of soliciting or peddling in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(Code 1984, § 19-28; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-51. - Same-Notice of hearing. 
    Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license or identification card required by this division shall be given in writing by the city clerk setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known address at least five (5) days prior to the date for the hearing. 
(Code 1984, § 19-29; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-52. - Appeal following denial or revocation; entitlement. 
    Any peddler aggrieved by the action of the special magistrate revoking an identification card or license as provided in section 21-50 may file a petition for a writ of certiorari in the circuit court for the fifteenth judicial district within 30 days of the decision. 
(Code 1984, § 19-30; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 21-53. - Unauthorized use of identification card. 
    No identification card issued pursuant to this division shall be used at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Code 1984, § 19-24; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 5-24-2011) 
Secs. 21-54-21-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - (RESERVED) 

Secs. 21-71-21-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Solicitation of funds, F.S. Ch. 496; more stringent local provisions not preempted, F.S. § 496.34. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 21-116-21-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 21-126. - Purpose of division. 
    The purpose of this division is to protect the inhabitants of the city from being imposed upon by persons posing as representatives of recognized charitable institutions, posing as representatives of fictitious or nonexisting charitable organizations, or soliciting funds under the guise of soliciting for charity when the persons are not lawfully employed by such charitable organizations. Nothing in this division is intended in any way to interfere with the work of recognized charitable or benevolent institutions, but to protect them and the persons wishing to donate to such organizations from being taken advantage of by unauthorized representatives of spurious organizations, by representatives of fictitious and nonexisting charitable or benevolent organizations, or by representatives of newly created organizations, the purpose of such newly created organizations being to benefit the solicitors rather than the public. 
(Code 1984, § 19-76) 
Sec. 21-127. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit funds or donations of money or of property of any kind for charitable or benevolent purposes without first obtaining a permit from the mayor for such purpose. In the absence of the mayor, a permit may be issued or denied by the city clerk. 
(Code 1984, § 19-77) 
Sec. 21-128. - Applicant to supply certain information. 
    Each and every person desiring to solicit funds for himself or for others shall before engaging in such soliciting in the city procure from the mayor a permit, which permit shall be open to inspection by the chief of police or any police officer or any citizen of the city. Before the permit is issued, the applicant shall be required to supply in writing for the permanent records of the city his name, age, nationality and race, and how long the person has been employed for the charity that he purports to represent. In addition, the person must supply written evidence from the charitable or benevolent corporation he is said to represent, which evidence shows that the person is at the present time employed by the charitable or benevolent organization. Should a charitable or benevolent organization that is unknown or of new origin apply for a permit to collect funds or donations of any kind, it shall also supply in writing a statement of where such organization was organized, where its chief office is located, and for what purpose it solicits funds, and also whether or not any federal, state, city or town has supervision of its expenditures, or whether the public is fully apprised of the manner in which the donations are to be distributed. Should the applicant be soliciting funds on his own behalf, he shall submit satisfactory proof that he is a permanent cripple and cannot obtain entrance into a charitable institution, or that he is a veteran holding an honorable discharge from some branch of the United States Army or Navy, and that his physical condition will not permit him to do any more strenuous work than soliciting funds. 
(Code 1984, § 19-78) 
Sec. 21-129. - Appeal to city commission following denial. 
    Should any applicant for the permit required by this division be aggrieved at the ruling of the mayor or city clerk as to the issuance of a permit, they may apply to the city commission, and the city commission's ruling, either approving or disapproving the issuance of the permit, shall be final. 
(Code 1984, § 19-79) 
Chapter 22 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-7(5); ordinances relating to municipal street maintenance agreements saved from repeal, § 1-7(6); ordinances establishing or prescribing grades for streets saved from repeal, § 1-7(7); public services department, § 2-106; placing handbills on public property prohibited, § 3-29; consumption of alcoholic beverages upon public property, § 4-6; sale, provision or consumption of alcoholic beverages within public parks, § 4-7; possession, consumption at public school athletic events, in athletic arenas, § 4-8; dumping garbage and trash in streets, alleys and parks prohibited, § 11-12; report of transportation of garbage over streets required, § 11-12; expectorating on public sidewalks and floors of public buildings, § 12-1; junk and abandoned property, Ch. 13; mobile homes and recreational vehicles, Ch. 15; Pahokee Harbor, Ch. 18; planning, Ch. 19; public improvements, Ch. 20; use of public streets by peddlers, § 21-29; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 25; utilities, Ch. 26. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Obstructing, tearing up, repairing streets and sidewalks-Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do the following without first obtaining a written permit from the building inspector: 
(1)  Drive any truck over any curb, gutter or sidewalk in the city; 
(2)  Do any construction or repair work involving the tearing up and relaying of any street, alley, curb, gutter or sidewalk, or part of any street, alley, curb, gutter or sidewalk; 
(3)  Obstruct, dig into or in any way disturb any street, alley, curb, gutter, sidewalk, or part thereof; 
(4)  Remove any earth or muck from ditches in the city. 
(b)  The permit required by this section shall be issued under the terms of this chapter and under such conditions as may be further prescribed by the building inspector and shall accurately describe the portion of the street, alley, curb, gutter, sidewalk or culvert, if it is to be replaced in the same condition as when disturbed and shall state a definite time within which the permit shall be operative. 
(Code 1984, § 20-1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Same-Barricades and warning devices. 
(a)  Any person carrying on or doing any construction, excavation or repair work in any street, alley, sidewalk or ditch or part thereof in the city pursuant to a permit as required by section 22-1 shall erect and maintain proper, safe and sufficient barricades. During that period of time between one-half hour before sunset and one-half hour after sunrise such person shall maintain sufficient lights or flares around such barricades, work or excavations to warn persons of the presence of such excavations and work and to prevent injury to persons and property. Any excavations made by the agents or employees of the city for the purpose of uncovering a Y or other connections of the water system, or of opening or uncovering manholes or sanitary or storm sewers hereafter installed on or in excavations made to allow contractors to make connection with thereto shall be protected by barricades and lights by the plumbing contractor for whom the Y or other connection of the water or other systems of the city are uncovered. 
(b)  No person shall, without due authority, remove any light or flare placed in or near an excavation in a street, alley, or ditch while repairs or work is going on in such street, alley or ditch. 
(Code 1984, § 20-2) 
Sec. 22-3. - Same-Liability insurance required. 
    Before granting a permit to any person to do any construction, excavation or repair in any street, alley or sidewalk of the city, the building inspector shall require of the person to whom such permit is issued the following: 
(1)  A policy of liability insurance with some casualty company or insurance company duly authorized and qualified to transact business in the state with liability limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injuries to one (1) person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injuries to more than one (1) person which are received in the same accident; and 
(2)  Property damage limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), which policies shall insure the permit holder against liability for personal injuries and damage to property by reason of the negligence or misconduct of the holder of the permit, his employees and agents in the performance of any construction, excavation or repair work in any of the streets, alleys, and sidewalks or parts thereof in the city; 
(3)  Such certificate of insurance shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1984, § 20-3) 
Sec. 22-4. - Same-Replacing street, sidewalk. 
    Upon the expiration of any permit granted under the terms of this chapter, or before, if the work is completed before the expiration date of the permit, the permit holder shall replace that portion or part of any street, alley or sidewalk upon which construction, excavation or repair work has been performed in the same condition as such portion or part of any street, alley or sidewalk existed prior to the construction, excavation or repair work. 
(Code 1984, § 20-4) 
Sec. 22-5. - Grades for curbs, sidewalks, culverts, streets-Authority of city to establish. 
    The city is authorized from time to time to establish grades for curbs, sidewalks, culverts and street grades. 
(Code 1984, § 20-5) 
Sec. 22-6. - Same-Owners to obtain grades before commencing work. 
    Any owner of land or his agents or contractors who build sidewalks or culverts or who build new streets in land subdivided or to be subdivided must, in addition to the other requirements or other ordinances pertaining to such matters, obtain the curb grade, culvert grade and street grade before entering into such work. 
(Code 1984, § 20-6) 
Sec. 22-7. - Same-Builders on business lots to obtain grade. 
    All persons building on business lots before erecting a building on a business lot must obtain the curb and culvert grade. 
(Code 1984, § 20-7) 
Sec. 22-8. - Same-Penalty for violation of sections 22-5 through 22-7. 
    Any person who violates any part or portion of sections 22-5 through 22-7 shall be punished as provided in section 1-11, and the city commission shall have the right, in addition, to revoke any building permit for failure to comply herewith. 
(Code 1984, § 20-8) 
Sec. 22-9. - Culverts in city ditches. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to install any culvert in any ditches of the city without first having received a permit from the building inspector in charge of streets, which permit shall specify size culvert to be installed. 
(b)  All culverts used shall be of culvert iron pipe treated against rust or its equivalent. 
(c)  All culvert pipe installed by anyone other than the city or its employees shall not be covered up until inspected. 
(d)  Lights or flares shall be placed around culverts being constructed between sunset and sunrise. 
(Code 1984, § 20-9) 
Sec. 22-10. - Sidewalk specifications. 
(a)  All sidewalks built on public rights-of-way shall be not less than four (4) feet in width, excluding the curb, and four (4) inches thick except at driveway entrances where sidewalks shall be six (6) inches thick. Expansion plates shall be placed at least every ten (10) feet. They shall be installed so as to slope or drain towards the public street away from the private property line at the rate of fall of one-fourth inch per foot. The concrete shall consist of a five-bag mix reinforced by six (6) by six (6) by ten/ten wire mesh, unless otherwise authorized by the city commission. All sidewalks shall be constructed along the outside edge of the public right-of-way, along the private property line. 
(b)  In zones R-5 and R-6, as defined in the zoning code of the city, sidewalks may be constructed as specified in subsection (a) of this section on one-inch type I or II asphaltic concrete on a four-inch thick compacted base of locally approved limerock or shell. The base shall extend six (6) inches from each side of the surface. 
(Code 1984, § 20-17) 
Sec. 22-11. - Encroachments and obstructions generally on streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall build, plant or erect on any street or alley of the city any fence, building, wall, hedge, or tree nor shall any person put or place any of his personal property on any sidewalk or alley or street so as to cause an encroachment on the same. 
(b)  No person shall erect, construct, place or maintain any obstructions or encroachments whatever on the streets, sidewalks, or alleys of the city. 
(c)  No person shall suffer or permit any structure or building of any kind which encroaches from his property to continue to encroach onto any city street, alley or sidewalk. 
(d)  If any encroachment exists contrary to this section and the owner fails or refuses or neglects to remove or tear down the same within five (5) days after being notified so to do by the city inspector, the city inspector shall, under the direction of the city, tear down and remove such fence, wall, hedge, tree or building. 
(e)  The garden club or any citizen may plant trees on places reserved for trees by the city, with written permission from the city commission. 
(Code 1984, § 20-12) 
Sec. 22-12. - Obstruction of streets and sidewalks during building construction. 
(a)  Permit required to place building materials on streets or sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the construction or repair of any building to place or deposit or cause or allow to be placed or deposited on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place within the limits of the city any building material whatsoever, or any articles or things which may obstruct or hinder traffic thereon, without a written permit from the city inspector, which permit shall state clearly what space will be allowed on which the same may be placed or deposited, the length of time the permit shall remain in force and the terms and conditions upon which such material or other articles or things may be placed thereon. 
(b)  Sheds over sidewalks. When, in the discretion of the city inspector, it becomes necessary for the protection of pedestrians, the person erecting or repairing any building shall cause a shed to be erected over the sidewalk adjoining the property upon which the building is being constructed or repaired, the construction of which shed shall be in accordance with plans approved by the city inspector and the shed shall be maintained thereafter during the construction or repair of the building but under no condition shall the sidewalk be so obstructed as not to allow pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1984, § 20-16) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations generally, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 22-13. - Wire, cord, rope suspended across streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hang or suspend in any manner or means, any rope, cord or wire or other means of connection across any street or alley of the city for any purpose. Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from displaying banners or electric colored lights at holiday seasons when they are erected by the employees of the city with permission from the city commission. 
(Code 1984, § 20-13) 
Sec. 22-14. - Hauling logs, steel girders, other material through streets. 
    No person shall haul any logs, pilings, steel girders, pipes or other materials on the streets or alleys of the city in motor or other vehicles unless such logs, pilings, steel girders, pipes or other materials be securely fastened on such vehicle with chains, cables or ropes of sufficient fastening or strength to prevent the aforesaid articles from falling or rolling from such vehicle onto a street, alley or thoroughfare of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 20-14) 
Sec. 22-15. - Painting on streets, sidewalks, signs, poles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to draw, place or print or paint on any sidewalk, street or alley or on any street signpost, signal tower, traffic signpost or electric light standard in the city any character, letter, syllable, clause or sentence, whether in the form of any advertisement, declaration or otherwise; however, nothing in this section shall prevent duly constituted officers of the city from painting upon streets, sidewalks, curbs, poles, traffic posts, such traffic or directional signs as may be required. 
(Code 1984, § 20-11) 
Sec. 22-16. - Destroying and removing street signs, lamps, ornamental trees. 
    No person shall, without due authority, break, injure, deface, destroy, mutilate, take up, remove or carry away any street post or sign, streetlamp, lantern or flare, shade or ornamental tree located on the streets or public ways of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 20-10) 
Sec. 22-17. - Electric light poles on sidewalks. 
    Electric light poles shall be set on the sidewalk but as far as possible from the property line and as close to the curb or part of the sidewalk bordering the traveled way of the street as possible, and so set on cross streets as not to come in the center of any sidewalk on either street. 
(Code 1984, § 20-18) 
Sec. 22-18. - Planting trees on streets. 
    On streets covered by section 22-10(a), trees may be planted on the parkette nine (9) feet from the property line, and on streets covered by section 22-10(b) trees may not be planted. 
(Code 1984, § 20-19) 
Sec. 22-19. - Abatement of poles and trees violating chapter. 
    Poles erected or trees planted in violation of this chapter shall be deemed nuisances and may be abated as such. 
(Code 1984, § 20-20) 
Sec. 22-20. - Liability to city of person damaging streets. 
    Whoever damages any street or alley by trespassing thereon or using same unlawfully, shall, in addition to the penalties prescribed in section 1-11, be civilly liable to the city for the amount of such damages, which amount may be recovered in a suit by the city in the courts of the state having jurisdiction thereof. 
(Code 1984, § 20-15) 
Secs. 22-21-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET AND ROAD ABANDONMENT 

Sec. 22-31. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as "the city street and road abandonment article." 
(Ord. No. 94-2, § 1, 10-25-1994) 
Sec. 22-32. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish a uniform procedure for the vacation and abandonment of city streets, alleys, roads, highways, or other places used for travel. 
(Ord. No. 94-2, § 2, 10-25-1994) 
Sec. 22-33. - Closing and abandonment of roads; authority. 
(a)  The city commissioners, with respect to property under their control may in their own discretion, and of their own motion, or upon the request of any agency of the county, state or federal government, or upon petition of any person or persons, are hereby authorized and empowered to: 
(1)  Vacate, abandon, discontinue and close any existing public or private street, alleyway, road, highway, or other place used for travel, or any portion thereof, other than a county, state or federal highway, and to renounce and disclaim any right of the city and the public in and to any land in connection therewith; 
(2)  Renounce and disclaim any right of the city and the public in and to any land, or interest therein, acquired by purchase, gift, devise, dedication or prescription for street, alleyway, road or highway purposes, other than lands acquired for county, state and federal highway; and 
(3)  Renounce and disclaim any right of the city and the public in and to land, other than land constituting, or acquired for, a county, state, or federal highway, delineated on any recorded map or plat as a street, alleyway, road or highway. 
(b)  The commissioners, upon such motion, request, or petition, may adopt a resolution declaring that a definite time and place a public hearing will be held to consider the advisability of exercising the authority granted in this section. 
(Ord. No. 94-2, § 3, 10-25-1994) 
Sec. 22-34. - Closing and abandonment of roads; publication of notice. 
    Before any such road shall be closed and vacated, or before any right or interest of the city or public in any land delineated on any recorded map or plat as a road shall be renounced and disclaimed, the commissioners shall hold a public hearing, and shall publish notice thereof, one time, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least two (2) weeks prior to the date stated therein for such hearing. After such public hearing, any action of the commissioners, as herein authorized, shall be evidenced by a resolution duly adopted and entered upon the minutes of the city commission. The request of any agency of the county, state or of the United States, or of any person, to the commissioners to take such action shall be in writing and shall be spread upon the minutes of the commissioners; provided, however, that the commissioners of their own motion and discretion, may take action for the purposes hereof. Notice of the adoption of such a resolution by the commissioners shall be published one (1) time, within thirty (30) days following its adoption, in one (1) issue of a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The proof of publication of notice of public hearing, the resolution as adopted, and the proof of publication of the notice of the adoption of such resolution shall be recorded in the official records of Palm Beach County. 
(Ord. No. 94-2, § 4, 10-25-1994) 
Sec. 22-35. - Closing and abandonment of roads; ratification of prior actions. 
    The actions by the commissioners, heretofore taken, closing, vacating or abandoning any road as herein described, and appearing in the minutes of such commissioners, are hereby ratified, approved and confirmed in all respects, and such roads are declared closed, vacated and abandoned, consistent with the provisions of the resolution or other action of such commissioners, as shown by their minutes. 
(Ord. No. 94-2, § 5, 10-25-1994) 
Sec. 22-36. - Closing and abandonment of roads; termination of easement; conveyance of fee. 
    The act of any commissioners in closing or abandoning any such road, or in renouncing or disclaiming any rights in any land delineated on any recorded map as a road, shall abrogate the easement theretofore owned, held, claimed or used by or on behalf of the public and the title of fee owners shall be freed and released therefrom; and if the fee of road space has been vested in the city, same will be thereby surrendered and will vest in the abutting fee owners to the extent and in the same manner as in case of termination of an easement for road purposes. 
(Ord. No. 94-2, § 6, 10-25-1994) 
Secs. 22-37-22-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKS AND RECREATION 

Sec. 22-51. - Adoption of Palm Beach County parks and recreation ordinances. 
    The city commission hereby finds that it is in the best interest of the city to adopt certain existing Palm Beach County ordinances. There is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference the following Palm Beach County ordinances, except as otherwise noted below. These laws shall be in full force and effect in the city as if fully set forth in this section: 
21-18. Definitions. 
21-19. Regulation of vehicles within parks. 
21-20. Buildings and other property. 
21-21. Fire. 
21-22. Plant and wildlife protection and preserva- 
      tion. 
21-23. Control of nuisance animals. 
21-24. Swimming and wading. 
21-25. Boating. (Not adopted) 
21-26. Water skiing. 
21-27. Fishing. (Not adopted) 
21-28. Firearms. 
21-30. Camping. 
21-31. Horseback riding. (Not adopted) 
21-32. Animals. 
21-33. Alcoholic beverages. 
21-34. Fireworks and explosive. 
21-35. Park usage. 
21-36. Commercial activities. 
21-37. Reserved park/facility areas. 
21-38. Permits. 
21-39. Noise. 
21-41. Pollution of waters. 
21-42. Refuse, trash and litter. 
21-43. Public utilities. (Not adopted) 
21-44. Park hours. 
21-45. Enforcement. 
21-46. Penalties. 
Adoption of these ordinances shall not prohibit the city from adopting future city ordinances related to parks and recreation. To the extent that any existing city ordinance conflicts with these county ordinances, the city ordinance shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07, § 1(22-51), 5-8-2007) 
Sec. 22-52. - Park hours. 
    The city shall retain the authority to set park hours of operation within the city, should it be determined to be in the best interests of the city to do so. Park hours may be changed upon resolution by the city commission, or this responsibility may be delegated to the city manager, or the city's director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07, § 1(22-52), 5-8-2007) 
Sec. 22-53. - Permits. 
    Any permits required by these ordinances shall be applied through and administered by the city. Permit fees shall be payable and paid to the city. The city may adopt the permitting system used by the county for the use of park facilities or adopt its own system. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07, § 1(22-53), 5-8-2007) 
Sec. 22-54. - Enforcement. 
    Law enforcement shall have the authority to enforce these provisions within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07, § 1(22-54), 5-8-2007) 
Secs. 22-55-22-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TRESPASSING IN CITY PARKS 

Sec. 22-70. - Title; applicability. 
(a)  This article shall be known as the "City of Pahokee Parks Trespass Ordinance." 
(b)  All provisions of this article shall be applicable to city parks. 
(Ord. No. 2016-08 , §§ 1-3, 6-28-2016) 
Sec. 22-71. - Definitions. 
(a)  Applicable local law shall include the following: 
(1)  Intentionally damaging or destroying city property, real or personal, including but not limited to any building; bridge; table; bench; fireplace; railing; paving; water line or other public utility or parts of appurtenances thereof; posted sign, notice or placard whether temporary or permanent; monument; stake, post or other boundary marker; or other structure, equipment, facility or appurtenance whatsoever; or 
(2)  Removing a live plant, plant part or plant material from city property; or 
(3)  Molesting, harming, frightening, killing, trapping, hunting, chasing, shooting, throwing objects at, harassing, feeding, or otherwise inhibiting the natural movements and habits of any invertebrate, mammal, amphibian, reptile, fish or bird within the city. This paragraph shall not preclude fishing in a designated fishing area or removal of any nuisance wildlife or animal as authorized by the city. 
(4)  Removing or attempting to remove any wild animal, or the eggs or nests of any amphibian, reptile, fish, bird or invertebrate from city property. This paragraph shall not preclude fishing in a designated fishing area or removal of any nuisance wildlife or animal as authorized by the city. 
(5)  Using, discharging or possessing fireworks (other than a firework display permitted by the city) explosives, or substances that could be combined into an explosive mixture within city property; or 
(6)  Building or attempting to build any fire within city property except in such areas where fireplaces or grills are provided or as specifically authorized by a regulation or permit issued by the city or dropping, showing or otherwise depositing lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars or other flammable material within city property; or 
(7)  Having been found to have violated any provision of the city parks and recreation ordinance three or more times; or 
(8)  Violating a notice contained on a posted sign on city property. 
(b)  Applicable state law shall include Chapter 316 (State Uniform Traffic Control), Chapter 782 (Homicide), Chapter 784 (Assault; Battery; Culpable Negligence), Chapter 787 (Kidnapping; False Imprisonment; Luring or Enticing a Child; Custody Offenses), Chapter 790 (Weapons and Firearms), Chapter 794 (Sexual Battery), Chapter 796 (Prostitution), Chapter 800 (Lewdness; Indecent Exposure), Chapter 806 (Arson and Criminal Mischief), Chapter 810 (Burglary and Trespass), Chapter 812 (Theft, Robbery, and Related Crimes), Chapter 823, (Public Nuisances); Chapter 825, (Abuse, Neglect, and Exploitation of Elderly Persons and Disabled Adults), Chapter 827 (Abuse of Children), Chapter 828 (Animals: Cruelty, Sales, Animal Enterprise Protection), Chapter 843 (Obstructing Justice), Chapter 847 (Obscenity), Chapter 856 (Drunkenness; Open House Parties; Loitering; Prowling; Desertion), Chapter 859 (Poisons; Adulterated Drugs), and Section 877.03 (Breach of the Peace; Disorderly Conduct), Chapter 893 (Drug Abuse Prevention and Control). 
(c)  County property shall mean any facility, building or outdoor area that is part of a park or owned and/or operated by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2016-08 , §§ 1-3, 6-28-2016) 
Sec. 22-72. - Trespass notice; authorization to issue; appeal. 
(a)  Any county sheriff's deputy or law enforcement officer acting within his/her jurisdiction is authorized to issue a trespass notice to any individual who violates any applicable local law or applicable state law while on city property. 
(b)  Any person issued a trespass notice shall be prohibited from returning to the city property specified in the trespass notice as follows: 
(1)  For the first trespass notice, for a period of six (6) months. 
(2)  For the second trespass notice, for a period of one (1) year. 
(3)  For the third or subsequent trespass notice, for a period of two (2) years. 
(c)  A copy of the trespass notice shall be provided by mail or hand delivery to the trespass notice recipient with a copy provided to the employee or official having control over the city property. The trespass notice shall include the name and address of the trespass notice recipient, the date, the provision of law the trespass notice recipient has violated, a brief description of the offending conduct, the location of the offense, the name of the person issuing the trespass notice and a description of the city property to which the trespass notice recipient shall not return during the trespass notice period described in subsection (3)(b) of this section. The written trespass notice shall advise of the right to appeal and the location and telephone number for filing the appeal. The trespass notice shall include a warning that any person found on city property in violation of a trespass notice may be arrested for trespassing. 
(d)  Appeal of trespass notice. The trespass notice recipient shall have the right to appeal as follows: 
(1)  An appeal of a trespass notice must be filed, in writing, at the address listed on the trespass notice within ten (10) days of the issuance of the trespass notice. The appeal shall include the trespass notice recipient's (appellant) name, address, telephone number, electronic mail address and facsimile number, if any, a copy of the trespass notice, and a statement of the basis for the appeal. Failure to file a written appeal within ten (10) days of issuance of the trespass notice shall be deemed a waiver of the right to appeal. 
(2)  A filing fee in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall accompany the appeal of the trespass notice. 
(3)  Appeals shall be heard by a special magistrate with jurisdiction and authority to hear and decide alleged violations of the codes and ordinances enacted by the city. 
(4)  Within forty (40) days following the filing of the appeal, a hearing shall be held in front of a special magistrate. Notice of the hearing shall be provided to the appellant by U.S. mail, electronic mail, facsimile, certified mail or hand delivery. If the issuance of a trespass notice was predicated of a violation of applicable state law and the criminal case is pending before the county or circuit court, the appeal hearing shall be stayed until the resolution of that case. 
(5)  The hearing shall be open to the public and shall be recorded. 
(6)  At the hearing the burden of proof shall be on the city to demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that a violation of an applicable local law or applicable state law on city property has occurred. However, proof that the appellant has entered a plea of guilty, regardless of adjudication, to the underlying offense shall be admissible at the hearing as an admission against interest. 
(7)  If the appellant fails to attend the appeal hearing, the appeal shall be dismissed with prejudice. 
(8)  All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. Upon determination of the special magistrate, irrelevant, immaterial, or unduly repetitious evidence may be excluded, but all other evidence of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs shall be admissible, whether or not such evidence would be admissible in a trial in the courts of the State of Florida. 
(9)  The special magistrate may inquire of or question any witness present at the hearing. The appellant or his/her attorney and an employee or attorney representing the city shall be permitted to inquire of or question any witness present at the hearing. The special magistrate may consider testimony presented by any witness at the hearing. 
(10)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the special magistrate shall orally render his or her decision (order) upholding or overruling the trespass notice based on evidence entered into the record. If the special magistrate upholds the trespass notice, appellant shall be enjoined from returning to the city property specified in the trespass notice for a period provided in subsection (3)(b) above. The decision shall then be transmitted to the appellant in the form of a written order including findings of fact and conclusions of law consistent with the record. The order shall be transmitted by mail to the appellant within ten (10) days after the hearing and a copy shall be sent to the law enforcement agency whose officer issued the trespass notice. 
(11)  Any aggrieved party may appeal an order of the special magistrate to the circuit court of Palm Beach County. Such appeal shall not be a hearing de novo but shall be limited to appellate review of the record created before the special magistrate. Any appeal filed pursuant to this article shall be considered timely if filed within thirty (30) days of the execution of the order to be appealed. The city may assess a reasonable charge for the preparation of the record to be paid by the appellant in accordance with F.S. § 119.07. 
(12)  The trespass notice shall remain in effect during any appeal process, unless a stay pending review is entered by the special magistrate. 
(13)  A special magistrate shall have the power to:
